there were three large drawers—there used to be clothes put in them—I do not know whose clothes—there were many things put in that I did not know of—mine and my father's clothes were put in—I do not think any of my mo
ther's clothes were put there—there were shirts of mine and my father's—my mother used to look after our shirts—the three large drawers had locks on them—I believe they all had locks, except one of the small ones where the nails were—I never knew any other drawer to be locked than the one I had the bottle in—I am sure they never were.

CHARLES HUTCHINGS. I am between eight and nine years old. I slept with my brother in the room next to my father and mother—I remember bearing my father come home on the Saturday night before my mother died—I do not know what o'clock it was—I do not know how long it was after I had gone to bed—my mother was in bed, she got up, went down, and let him in, and he came up stairs, and went to bed—I heard something take place between him and my mother after he came home—I cannot recollect what it was—my mother said, "You have begun your games already"—I do not recollect what my father said—I have given an account of what he stated, before to-day—no one has told me not to state it now—he spoke loud—he said, "Hold your tongue"—I heard my mother call him a villain, and my father hit her—she was sitting up in bed—I did not see her—I heard her get out of bed and go down stairs, and I heard the front door shut when she went out—she slammed to the door—I do not recollect whether my father called out anything after her as she was going out—I told the gentleman who examined me what he said, one Saturday night after my mother's death—I remember going before the Coroner at the Garrick's Head, and to Mr. Sand
ham's office, in High-street, Deptford—I told Mr. Sandham what my father called out to my mother as she went down stairs.

Q. Then, now tell us what you told him, if it was true? A. He called her, "Oh you faggot!"—that was when she went up stairs—my father slammed the door when he came in, and said, "Oh you faggot!"—he then went up stairs to bed—then he struck her, and then she got up, and as she went down stairs, he said, "You had better not come near me to-night"—I saw nothing more of my father and mother till next morning at breakfast time.

COURT. Q. You say she went down, did she go out of the house? A. Yes—I heard the door shut—she pulled it to, hard—she did not slam it—she pulled it to, hard, with the knocker—I did not hear my mother come in again—I went to sleep shortly after.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Was your brother asleep at this time? A. Yes in the same bed with me—after breakfast next morning I went to school—I came back at twelve o'clock—I cannot remember who let me in—my mother was out in the yard, cutting some cabbages for dinner—I afterwards went out, and fetched the dinner beer—my mother did not eat so much at dinner as she generally did—when dinner was over, my father went up stairs to lie down, and my mother went to lie down in the back room, not the room where we slept, but in the room where we had out dinner—I do not know what room my father laid down in—he went up stairs—soon after that, I went again to school—I came back at half-past four—my mother did not go up stairs after dinner—when I came back, my father and mother were up stairs—I did not go up stairs to see—I knocked at the door twice when I came home, nobody came, and I got over the place—I did not find anybody down stairs—I made the fire, to get the kettle to boil for tea—while I was doing so, my father came down stairs—I do not know whether my brother came home—I did not see him there at tea time—my mother stayed up stairs—my brother was not there

at the time the tea was made—I saw my brother again at night—there was nobody there at the time the tea was made but my father and myself—my father made the tea—at the time the tea was making, my father had a bottle—I threw that bottle down the privy—my father gave it to me, and told me to throw it down the privy—the bottle was empty when he gave it to me—I saw him take something out of it before he gave it to me—I do not know what it was—it was white stuff—I do not know whether it was white powder—there was white stuff in the bottle—he put that into the fire—as soon as he gave me the bottle, I took it to the privy, and threw it down—the tea was not poured out when I came back—the tea was made, there were the cups and saucers—when I came back, there was no tea in them—some tea was put is them after I came back—my father poured it out, and took some up stairs for my mother—I do not know whether he took up one cup, or more than one—I took some up afterwards—I do not know how soon it was after my father took up some tea that I took some up—it was at the same tea time—when I took it up, I found my mother in the room where my brother and I sleep—I said, "Father has sent you some tea," and put it down by her—she was lying on the bed—I do not know whether she appeared to be well or ill—she was lying on the bed with her clothes on—I afterwards went and fetched the cap and saucer away—my mother promised to give me something for attending to her, and spoke kindly to me—when I went up with the tea, I noticed that one of the small drawers was drawn out of the chest of drawers—I took the cup and saucer down stairs, and gave them to my father or put them down—he was down stairs—I did not notice whether my brother was there then—my brother Tom was not there—I do not know where Tom had his tea that day—when I came down, and put the cup and saucer down, my father gave me a halfpenny, and told me to go out and play—I then went out.

Cross-examined. Q. When you were examined by the gentleman at Deptford, were you promised anything, or told that you would be punished? A. No—it was about six o'clock on the Sunday evening when I saw my father making the tea—I had thrown the bottle down the privy before he made the tea.

COURT. Q. Before he put the water in the tea-pot? A. Yes—I saw him put the water in the tea-pot—I saw him put the water in the tea-pot after I took the bottle out to throw it into the privy—it was after I came back that I saw him take the tea out, and put it into the tea-pot—he did not put any water into the pot and wash it out first—he took the grouts out and chucked them away—he gave me the grouts to chuck away—he gave them to me in the tea-pot—I emptied the grouts out of the tea-pot and brought it him back again—that was after throwing the bottle away—I do not know how many tea-cups there were on the table—I had some tea out of the same tea-pot—there was sugar and milk in it—the tea-cups were kept on the shelf—I got them down, after I had thrown the bottle away—I am quite sure that I took up a cup of tea to my mother, and that my father did also—I am quite sure my father did—I saw the tea poured out into the cup that he took up, and the sugar and milk put to it—I cannot recollect whether we had anything to eat at tea—my father did not take my mother anything to eat—I do not know how he carried the tea up—I saw him go up stairs with it—he took hold of the saucer—I do not know whether he held it with both hands, because it was so full—I do not know how long it was before he came down again—he waited till she had drank the tea, and then he brought down the empty cup—I do not know whether he used the cup afterwards for himself or not—I do not know whether he took any tea himself afterwards—I cannot recollect—I

drank some tea after he had come down—he took some tea with me—after I took the tea up to my mother, I sat sown to drink my own tea—I do not recollect whether my father sat down and drank tea with me—I do not know whether my father went without his tea that evening—I ate something with my tea—my father cut me some bread and butter—I do not know whether he cut any for himself—I went out directly after I had my tea—my father was sitting in the room where I was—he was sitting at the same table where the tea was—the cup that I took up to my mother I took off the table when it was full of tea and took it up to my mother—there were three cups on the table, one for me, one for father, and one for mother—I did not pour out any of the tea—two cups had been poured out when my father went up with the first cup, one for my mother, and one for me—when my father came down he sent me up with the second cup—my father generally drinks tea—I do not know how long I was sitting at the table at my own tea after I came down from my mother—when I went away, I left my father sitting at the table—there was a cup before him, and the tea-pot on the table—all the thing were on the table, and I left him sitting at the table.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did your father cut the bread and butter after he had come down from taking the tea up to your mother? A. Yes, that was for me.
JURY. Q. What was done with the empty cup which your father brought down? A. Put on the table—I cannot tell what was done with it before I took up another cup of tea for my mother.

COURT. Q. Do you recollect whether you took up the tea in the same cup that your father had taken the tea in to your mother; was the same cup filled up again? A. I do not know—I do not know whether he threw she dregs out of the cup that he brought down, before he put more tea into it.

THOMAS WHEELER. I am ostler to Messrs. Blackmans, the coopers, where the prisoner and his son worked. About three months before his wife's death, I gave the prisoner a bottle with some arsenic in it—I gave it him because the said the cats ran away with the boy's chickens—the father and the boy both told me so—the bottle was little better than half full of white arsenic.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know that arsenic was a thing to use for that purpose? A. I had used it for poisoning rats—I told the prisoner I had used it for poisoning rats—it was a small bottle—there was a label tied round the neck of the bottle with "Arsenic, poison," upon it.

WILLIAM COCKLE. I am one of the beadles of Deptford parish—I searched the prisoner's premises, and found five packets and one bottle, which I handed over to Mr. Heisch—the packets were alongside the fire-place, in a corner, not in a cupboard, but on the top of a shelf—they were tied up as they were when I gave them to Mr. Hiecsh—I never had them unfolded—I found the bottle on the shelf alongside the packets—I was not present when any bottle was found in the privy—the bottle I speak of was found on the shelf—I know nothing of any other.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find any tea-cups and tea-pot? A. I searched them all on the 27th, but I never looked at them.
COURT. Q. What did you do with the paper packets? A. I took them to the hospital, and gave them to the medical gentleman—I delivered them to him exactly in the same condition in which I found them.

WILLIAM SPACEY. I am a constable, of Deptford—I searched the privy of the house where the prisoner lived, and I found a bottle—I gave it to Mr. Heisch in the same in which I found it—I assisted in taking the pri
soner into custody on the Friday after the inquest, the 27th I think—I told

him what I took him for—he said he was innocent—he went quietly part of the way—he then called me a b—and would not go—when we came to St. Paul's Churchyard, he said he wanted to make water—I followed him close behind—he said, "Are you frightened?"—I said, "No"—he said, "You b—, you could not take me, nor two b—b—s likewise"—I got a City police
man, and we took him.

COURT. Q. Did he resist being taken, or run away? A. No—he walked back, and up with his fist to strike me, and said, "You b—, stand up"—I had my truncheon in my hand, and struck him, or else he would have got away form me—he put his hand in the attitude of striking, which made me strike—he went quietly with the assistance of two City policemen.

CHARLES HEISCH. I am a lecturer upon practical chemistry at St. Thomas's Hospital. I have examined these five packages, two of them contain jalap, one contains carbonate of magnesia, another some pills, and another some brown sugar—the pills appear to be composed of common aloes, commonly called bitter aloes—I also examined the bottle—it had no label round it—it had apparently contained some organic matter in a state of decomposition, but it was impossible to state what it was, it was so completely decomposed—this is not the bottle that was taken from the privy—the bottle taken from the privy contained a quantity of night soil and traces of arsenic—there was certainly enough to enable me to say that the bottle had contained white arsenic (the bottle was here produce)—it has no label on it, nor had it when it was given to me—I was not present at the post-mortem examination—I received the stomach from Dr. Taylor—I submitted it to a chemical test, and found that it contained a considerable quantity of white arsenic—I was afterwards present when the kidneys were taken out—I submitted them to the same analysis, and they also contained arsenic—I succeeded in reproducing arsenic to the extent of about fifteen grains, some portion of which I have here—(producing several small tubes)—this is arsenic in the metallic condition in which it came from the contents of the stomach, and this is some in the state of white arsenic—at my last experiment I found this white arsenic in a pure state to adhere to one side of this tube—fifteen grains would be quite sufficient to cause death—this other tube contains fifteen grains of arsenic—it is a about the same in bulk as an ordinary pinch of snuff, that might he held between the fingers.

COURT. Q. Would tea hold it in solution? A. To a certain extent it would, but it would be more suspended in the fluid than actually in solu
tion—it would be held in the tea for a short time, but being rather neavy it would soon settle to the bottom—it would settle, perhaps, in the course of three or four minutes.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Supposing a person to stir the tea, as is usual, before taking it, it would then be sufficiently buoyant to be taken in it? A. Yes, it might then be taken—arsenic is as nearly tasteless as possible—supposing fifteen grains of arsenic to be put in a cup of tea, sweetened with sugar, and milk in it, it would not be detected by the taste—I did not see the deceased during her life.

Cross-examined. Q. In extracting this amount from the kidneys and stomach, you allow, I suppose, a good deal for loss; there must have been a great deal more than that taken into the stomach? A. Yes—it would be difficult to say whether there was double—it would depend a good deal upon the evacuations that took place after the poison had been taken.
COURT. Q. From what do you infer the fact of more having been taken into the stomach? A. From the fact of her having vomited frequently.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you that you extracted the whole that there was in the stomach at the time? A. Yes—if anything is allowed for loss it would be but a few hundredths of a grain—the taking of arsenic produce a burning sensation in the throat—that comes on some little time afterwards—in some cases it will take half an hour or more, it is very uncer
tain—the operation of arsenic is extremely uncertain in point of time, vary
ing from half an hour to four or five—the sickness usually begins with pains in the stomach, but that is also uncertain—sickness frequently comes on a very short time afterwards, but sometimes we find cases where sickness does not occur at all—the pain is principally in the stomach and back part of the throat—that would render a person indisposed to eat or drink—sometimes it causes considerable thirst—they feel disposed to take cold liquids, but indis
posed to take their food—very probably a little eaten would bring on retching and sickness.

COURT. Q. In what period of time would the indisposition to eat com
monly arise? A. It would be very difficult to say, it would depend so much upon the period at which the person began to eat before taking the arsenic—if it is taken upon a full stomach it does not act so speedily as if it is taken upon an empty stomach—if it was taken about an hour before dinner, probably at dinner time the person would not feel disposed to eat—that is the ordinary consequence of an exhibition of arsenic.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You have some powders there? A. Yes, they were brought to me by the beadle as having been found in the house—amongst them there is an aloetic pill—it is what is usually called bitter aloes—it contains bitter aloes—it is an aperient medicine—here is also some jalap—jalap is about as innocent a medicine as anybody can take—it some
times slightly irritates the stomach—it not unfrequently causes a little nausea—it is a mild aperient—there is no direction upon these powders as to the amount to be taken—I could not tell whether was any jalap in the stomach—jalap is a vegetable—I did not apply any test to ascertain the existence of any vegetable matter in the stomach, and am not able to state whether there was any vegetable poison or medicine in the stomach at that time—if she had taken any large quantity of jalap in the course of the day upon which she died, I might possibly have found some traces of it in the stomach, but after so much vomiting it would be unlikely.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Would it be at all unlikely, a person's stomach being deranged, that jalap should cause vomiting? A. It would be extremely likely, it is a nauseous medicine—that vomiting, if caused by taking jalap or an aloetic medicine, would indispose the party to eat—a deranged stomach alone would indispose a party to eat—the immediate action of arsenic is by eating into the coats of the stomach—if the stomach is empty the arsenic is more quick in its operation—if it was taken an hour before dinner, upon an empty stomach, and caused nausea and vomiting, I should expect those symptoms to be accompanied by violent heat and pain in the region of the stomach—that would probably precede the vomiting.

Q. Then, suppose a person to have taken jalap, and to have been sick and indisposed to eat at dinner-time, and not to complain of any burning heat or sensation of pain at the stomach, would you think that the fact of the jalap having been taken, would account for that state of things? A. Certainly, more naturally than if arsenic had been taken in the mean time.

DR. CALEB TAYLOR. I was present at the examination of the body of the deceased, and took out the kidneys—I did not take out the stomach—it was brought to me by Mr. Downing, sealed up—he gave it me as the stomach of
the deceased, and I handed it to Mr. Heisch—I handed the kidneys to Mr. Heisch—I was not present when he instituted his chemical analysis.

EDWARD DOWNING. I am a surgeon. I was called to the deceased's home about nine o'clock on Saturday evening, the 22nd of Aug.—I found her up stairs—she complained of great thirst, constant vomiting, violent pain of the bowels, and involuntary diarrhoea—she did not complain of her throat—I felt her pulse, and found that the power of life was rapidly sinking—I asked her what she had taken, and I understood, I think, from Mrs. Bywater that she had taken some jalap—when I arrived at the house the prisoner sent the boy into the next-door neighbour, Mrs. Bywater—she acme in immediately, and went up stairs first, and I followed her—I did not learn from the deceased that she had taken anything—it was Mrs. Bywater, in her presence—I immediately gave her some brandy and water, and also requested some one to go to my house for some medicine, to lose no time; and I gave her some astringent medicine, as the diarrhoea was so severe—I considered from the symptoms, that it was an attack of cholera—I remained there some few minutes—I did not see her again—I was not sent for again—understand she died about one that morning—I saw the prisoner on the Sunday evening—I told him his wife was seriously ill, dangerously ill; and I would do all I possibly could for her—he did not make any reply—he said he would send for the medicine directly, and Mrs. Bywater said she would come for it.

Q. Did he give you any reason to believe that his wife had taken arsenie or any poison whatever? A. None whatever—he heard what I said—he said nothing at all to me about the situation of his wife—he was down stairs when I saw him—I only saw him once—he opened the door to me, I think, when I went in—I waited while he sent next door for Mrs. Bywater—I should think I was alone with him, altogether, seven or eight minutes—I then west up stairs with Mrs. Bywater—when I came down again I found him down stairs, and then I said that his wife was seriously ill, in great danger—he said nothing to me about her, on either occasion—I examined the body after
wards—I took out the stomach, and gave it to Dr. Taylor—Mrs. Bywater applied to me on the following morning for a certificate, which I refused—I was the first person that opened the body—I had no doubt then from the appearances that presented themselves, that her death was caused by poison—I have no doubt of it now—the stomach was highly inflamed, and also the duo
denum—I did not examine the throat—there were appearances which justi
fied me in taking out the stomach, and submitting it to a chemical analysis.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask the prisoner any question as to what his wife had taken in the course of the day? A. No, nor did I ask Mrs. By
water—the woman herself was rapidly sinking, she was hardly able to articu
late—I remained there seven or eight minutes, altogether—not less than that—I think it was seven minutes—I did not inquire what food she had taken that day.

THOMAS HUTCHINGS
re-examined. I went out in the morning with the beef to the baker's, in my old trowsers—I changed my clothes before dinner—I do not think it was long before—I do not think it was above half as hour—I went up into my own room to change them—I did not go to the drawer in which I had the arsenic—I had an opportunity then of seeing the outside of the drawer—the drawers were all in their places at that time—I am quite sure of that—I observed nothing like a breakage of my small drawer—it was not out in the room—I came down after I had changed my clothes—my father did not go up stairs to my room afterwards, before we sat down

to dinner, that I saw; I never saw him go up—he was not down stairs when I was changing my clothes—he was out—he came home while I was gone for the dinner—I found him at home when I returned—I did not go into my room again till tea-time—we dined between one and two—I do not think I stopped in the house longer than half an hour after dinner—when I left the house after dinner, my father was gone up stairs to lie down—my mother did not go up too—I do not think my mother went up at all before I left the house—I cannot say exactly how long before I left the house, my father had gone up stairs; but I do not think more than a quarter of an hour.

GUILTY. Aged 43.—
DEATH.

2218.
JOHN PRITCHARD was indicted
stealing 2 pewter pots, value 3s. 4d.; the goods of
George Mason.

GEORGE MATTHEWS. I am servant to Mr. George Mason, a market-gar
dener and a publican; he keeps the Windmill, at Deptford. On the 1st of Sept. I saw two pots in a shed in his binding-ground—these pots produced are my master's property.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When had you seen them in this garden? A. At half-past seven in the evening—the garden adjoins the high road—I have seen the prisoner about three years before—he then used my master's house—I am foreman and salesman in the market-gardening business.

JOHN PAVOR (policeman M 147.) I was on duty at half-past two o'clock in the night on the 1st. of Sept.—I came up to the prisoner, and asked what he had got under his jacket—he made no answer—I took him by the collar, put my hand under his jacket, and pulled out this quart pot—I put my hand under his other arm and pulled out this other—I asked whose they were—he said, "I believe they belong to Mr. George Mason, of the Windmill public-house"—he said he had picked them up under the hedge—I asked if he worked for him—he said, "No"—I asked how he came to take these pots, if he did not work for him—he then said he did work for him—I asked where he lived—he said, "In the brick-field," which is about a quarter of a mile from the spot—I said I must take him to the station—he became very violent—I threw him on the ground and made an alarm—my brother officer came, and we took him to the station.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he was going to take them home, and take them to Mr. Mason next day? A. Yes, when I asked him, he said he was going to take care of them—he was not drunk—I could not say whether he had been drinking or not.

JURY to GEORGE MATTHEWS. Q. Were the post in the shed in the gar
den? A. Yes—the garden is enclosed by a hedge—the shed-door was shut—no one had any right there from the time I shut up the shed till the next morning.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 31.—
Confined Three Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2219.
JOHN WILLIAMS and
HENRY JONES were indicted for
steal
ing at
Lee , 1 watch, value 55l. the goods of
Charlotte Frederics Lock, in the dwelling-house of
George Lock.
ELIZABETH GENERY. I am housemaid to Charlotte Frederics Lock, who

lives at Lee, in the dwelling-house of George Lock—her bed-room looks to the churchyard—I saw her watch safe between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning on the 7th of Aug., on her dressing-room table—Miss Lock missed it on retiring to bed that evening.

WILLIAM HEARNDEN. I am carpenter, and work at Mr. Brann's, at Lee, next door to Mr. Lock's. On Saturday afternoon, the 7th of Aug., between three and four o'clock, I saw the prisoners with another man, opposite my employer's—I ordered them out of the field—they came towards the church-yard—two of them went in and one stood outside—I did not see any more of them till the Tuesday following.
FRANCIS HOSIER HART. I was passing the churchyard on the 7th of Aug., at half-past three o'clock—I saw Williams come from the direction of Mr. Lock's house, across the churchyard.

THOMAS TAYLOR. I was locked up in the station-house, waiting for bail—the prisoners came in on the Tuesday—they said they were locked up for stealing a gold watch—Williams said Jones climbed up the spout and chucked it out, and Williams sold it to George Gray, who kept a fence in Mint-street Borough, that there was another one in it, but he was not there, he was gone into the country, that they went down on the Tuesday with the intention of screwing the drum, meaning, "to rob the house, "for one to get I and wait till the people were gone to bed, and then let the other in to rob the house.
Williams's Defence. He asked me whether I had the watch; I told him, "No;" I am innocent of it.

2220.
WILLIAM JAMES STUBBINS was indicted
for stealing 20 knives and forks, value 14s.; 1 roasting-jack, 12s.; 2 pairs of snuffers 2s.; 2 brushes, 2s.; 1 broom, 3s.; 1 strainer, 1s.; 1 pair of scissors, 3s. 8 skewers, 1s.; 1 cork-screw, 1s.; 2 sauce-ladles, 7s.; 4 spoons, 4s.; 6 knives, 4s.; 1 razor, 1s.; and 1 dressing-case, 4s.; the goods of
John Wilson Newhall, his master.

JOHN WILSON NEWHALL. I am ironmonger, and live in Powis-street, Woolwich. The prisoner was in my service since last March—I lost a variety of things—I went with an officer and the prisoner to his house—we found there his wife, and he acknowledged it was his house—we found there all this property produced—I will not say the whole of it is mine, I believe it is—three or four things I will positively swear to.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What do you swear to? A. I have known this dressing-case ten years—it happened not to be a saleble article—it is marked by myself, in my own writing, and by a man whose writing I can swear to—I can swear to these toilet-snuffers, and to this hair broom, which is marked in my private character by my apprentice, who is now in my shop—here is a brush with the private mark scratched out—I could almost say my private mark is here, but I will not—it is not possible for me to say I missed all these articles—it is merely because I saw them four articles that I swear to them—I can produce duplicates to some of then—most of them are marked—three person sell in my shop—we went to the prisoner's house—he took us into the room where these things were—we made him believe we wanted a pig-trough—he had no idea we wanted these things.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman R 122.) I got into the room, and asked the prisoner if it was his—he said, "Yes"—I found this dressing-case—I asked him where he got it—he said he look it from Mr. Newhall's—I found
these ladles—I asked him how he got then—he said he took them from Mr. Newhall's—I found a number of other things there.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he got them from Mr. Newhall's? A. No, he said he took them—he first told us he had no property of Mr. Newhall's.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 31—recommended to mercy by the prosecutor and Jury. —
Confined Four Months

2221.
EDWARD ADAMS was indicted
for stealing 3 shawls, value 3l.; 21 handkerchiefs, 3l.; 27 1/4 yards of stain, 5l. 10s.; 12 pair of stockings 2l. 17s.; 2 yards of cloth, 30s.; 1 1/2 yards of cambric, 12s.; 2 veils, 11s.; 2 scarfs, 7s.; 4 yards of ribbon, 4s.; 1 collar, 3s.; and 5 laces, 3s.; the good of
Francis William Vant, his master.

THOMAS DANES. I am in the service of Francis William Vant, draper, at Woolwich—the prisoner was his shopman—as I was shutting up at night, on the 12th Aug., I noticed a parcel on a shelf close by the warehouse door—I went up stair, and stated what I saw—I went down again, and the parcel was gone—I afterwards saw the prisoner take the same parcel out of his box—this is it (produced)—these goods are Mr. Vant's.
EDWARD MOODY. I was present when the box was searched—I have heard Davis's evidence—it is correct.

GUILTY.—recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
confined Nine Months

2222.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing 3 yards of corduroy, value 3s. 9d.; the good of the
Guardians of the Poor of St. George-the-Martyr, Southwark, his matters.

ELIZABETH SARAH O'BRIEN. I am matron of the workhouse of St. George-the-Martyr, Southwark, at the Lewisham—the prisoner was tailor there, at weekly wages—it was his business to cut out corduroy—he had no business to take any away—I have missed corduroy—I have seen some which is made into a pair of trowsers which Miller has on—I believe it is ours, but cannot swear to it—these other pieces I believe to be the same—they belong to the guar
dians of the poor of that parish.
CHARLSE MILLER. I am ostler at the Castle, at Lewisham—the prisoner made me this pair of corduroy trowsers which I have now on.
EDWIN BOURNE. The prisoner asked me to carry a parcel to Price from the workhouse-yard—it appeared to be cord or jean—I did so.
JOHN PRICE. I received these pieces of corduroy from the prisoner.
CHARLES LLOYD (policeman, R 199.) I produce three pieces of corduroy, which I got from price.

Prisoner's Defence. I made two suits of clothes a week; I had two yards, or two yards and a half, according to the size of the lads; had I been short, I should have had to have made up the deficiency; I save pieces from the general cutting from one time to another.

JURY to ELIZABETH SARAH O'BRIEN. Q. was that the contract? A. No, it was not—I bought everything that I gave him—I gave him out some
times five yards, and sometimes six yards, to make a suit of clothes—if he had any over he would use it for repairing the old suits—he had no right to keep any himself.

GUILTY. Aged 22.—
confined Three Months.

2223.
HEZEKIAH BURBAGE was indicted
for unlawfully having in his possession certain naval stores, marked with the broad-arrow, the pro
perty of
our Lady the Queen.

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180.) On the 19th of Aug. I was on duty in High-street, Deptford—I saw the prisoner driving a cart—I knew him before—I did not notice whether there was anything in it—he went with it to Hedges', a marine-store dealer, in High-street, Deptford, he got out of the cart, and went to a side gateway, attached to Mr. Hedge's shop—after remaining there about two minutes, two of Mr. Hedge's men came out of the yard, undid the tailboard, and took from the cart a basket covered with a cloth, and carried it into Mr. Hedge's yard (I did not see the prisoner at that time)—I followed into the yard, and saw the basket on the ground—the prisoner stood by it—I asked him what it contained—he said, "Copper"—I asked him to let me look at it—he said he would with the greatest pleasure—one of Hedge's men undid the cloth—I looked, and saw this copper in the basket—here are a great many pieces, weighing in all about 126lbs—I asked the pri
soner how he accounted for it—he told me he bought it at different shop a Woolwich—I told him I was not satisfied, and should take him before a Magistrate, which I did—I examined the basket at the station, and found one piece with the broad-arrow on it—this is it—I knew the prisoner to be a marine-store dealer.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have any of the other copper articles the broad-arrow on them? A. No—I knew where the prisoner lived—he went to the station very readily—he has a small shop, and Mr. Hedges' is a large wholesale shop—it is in the ordinary course of business for small dealers to sell to large dealers.

WILLIAM WOODS. I am a clerk in the store-keeper's office, in Woolwich Dock-yard—I have looked at the copper produced—here is one piece with the broad-arrow on it, marked distinctly, and there are other pieces in which the broad-arrow appears to be defaced—these bolts generally appear to have been operate upon with a file—I conclude they have been field for the pur
pose of obliterating the mark, never having seen bolts so operated on before—the value of this copper would be about 3l. 10s. or 3l. 12s.—this pieces that is marked weight about 14lbs. and is worth 6 1/2d. per pound—materials of this kind are never sold by Government, they are all sent to Portsmouth or Chatham to be re-manufactured.

Cross-examined. It must have been a very broad-arrow that has been filed out of this piece. A. The broad-arrow is stamped all over them, at about two inches or two inches and a half distance—it is not all over this piece, this may not have been a manufactured bolt—it is used for the purpose of sepa
ting materials—I went to ask the men what it was used for to satisfy myself and any one that might ask—I did not know without asking.
MR. PETERSDORF. Q. Has it the broad-arrow on it? A. Yes.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY—Recommended to mercy by the Jury —
Fined 5 l.,
Confined one Moths

2224.
ELIZABETH DABBS was indicted for
stealing I watch, value 2l.; and 1 watch-chin, value 2d.; the goods of
George Cock; and
SARAH DABBS
for feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to be stolen.
AMELIA COCK. I am the wife of George Cock, a pensioner—we live in East-street, Greenwich—on the 5th of Aug. I met my husband in a public-house—we

went along Trafalgar-road—we met Elizabeth Dabbs' father, and then the two prisoners—we walked along Trafalgar-road—my husband said he would have his dinner—I fetched it, and we all had a little, and had two pots of beer between five of us—we then went towards Woolwich—it rained. we turned back, and called in at the Fathers—my husband said I had better go home and get tea—I went home, and Elizabeth Dabbs followed me—I lighted the fire, and got tea—my husband came home—he and I, and Elizabeth Dabbs had tea and supper together—my husband said he would go to bed, and took his watch from the hook by the chimney-piece, wound it up, and hung it on the same hook again—Elizabeth Dabbs was standing tying her bonnet, and looking at the Chimney-glass—the instant he hung the watch up she snatched it, and ran away—I ran after her to the Red Lion—her mother, Sarah Dabbs, was standing at the entrance of the Red Lion—Elizabeth thrust both her hand in her mother's bosom—I saw the watch-chain hanging down—her mother closed her bosom—I said, "Give me the watch"—Sarah Dabbs said, "I wish I had it"—they went home—I went with them—Elizabeth's father was sitting in the ground-floor room, in the dark—they went in, and in two or three minutes all three came out into the yard, and the father said, "There will be a rare bother with this, I am glad I was not there"—he said to his daughter, "You have been in the Peniten
tiary—she said, "I know I have"—she said to me, "My mother will give it you in the morning."

Sarah Dabbs. You said you would not give me in charge. Witness. There was no such word said—the policeman said, "I see, the girl has bounced you out of your watch, so, old woman, you had better go home;" and two days afterwards that policeman was discharged for being a bad character.

GEORGE COCK. I had the watch—I would it up at a quarter before ten, and placed it on the hook again—it was perfectly safe—in a short time I saw Elisabeth Dabbs run out of the room with it—my wife ran after her, as I had got my boots off.

Elizabeth Dabbs. You know you were perfectly tipsy, you could not fol
low me. witness. I was perfectly sober.

Elizabeth Dabbs' Defence. I did not take it, nor did my mother; Mr. Cock asked me to make tea, as she was not able—I then went and told my mother to come; we wanted to have a pint of beer; my mother said, "I have got a penny in my bosom;" I was feeling for it; this women came, and said, "Did you see my husband's watch?" I said, "No;" my mother said, "I hope you do not accuse my daughter;" she said, "No;" the policeman and she came, searched the room, and it was not there; the policeman is not on duty now.

Sarah Dabbs' Defence. The policeman came, my wish; there was no watch; I said, "I hope you don't think my daughter has got it;" she said, "No; my husband is in the habit of putting it away, and he has done so;" I said, "Here is the policeman; "he came and searched, and said, "Shall I take them in charge?" she said, "No; my husband has mislaid it before, he may have done it again;" we went to two public-houses, and then to the Feathers; we had all had enough; Mrs. Cock swore the watch was on the table, and next time she it was on the hook.

AMELIA COCK
re-examined. My husband never mislaid his watch—I never said so—we were all perfectly sober—Dabbs was at home in the dark when the prisoners went home—the door was open—they had no key.

ELIZABETH DABBS—
GUILTY. Aged 17.—
confined Three Months.

SARAH DABBS—
GUILTY. Aged 44.—
confine six Month. >

2225.
WILLIAM STONEHAM was indicted
for unlawfully attempting to commit b—st—y.

2226.
CATHERINE HERION was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of bellows, value 2s. 6d.; 1 candlestick, 2s. 6d.; and 1 watch-guard, 4d.; the goods of
Phillip Kreckeler.

ESTHER KRECKELER. I am the wife of Phillip kreckeler—we keep a toy-shop, in London-street, Greenwich. On the 30th of Aug., between one and two o'clock, the prisoner came to me, and purchased a toilet-bottle—these was a pair of bellows, some china candlestick, and an India-rubber watch-guard on the counter—she was in the shop about half-an-hour—she only purchased the toilet-bottle—I served her—she gave me five sixpence—I did not miss anything after she was gone, but was sent for to Mrs. Smaill's, up the court by the side of my shop, and saw my property there—I had not sold it—nobody serves in the shop but me—these bellows, guard, and candle-sticks (produced) are mine.

Prisoner. Q. Do you recollect what passed, when I purchased a chain of you? A. There was a chain sent home for your daughter to look at, and if she did not like it I was to take it back—you did not say you would pay for these thing when you got the chain—I did not say, "Take what you please, the money is sure"—your servant was with you—I had not told you to out at my shop at any time, and I would give you a glass of porter—I did say to you that the bellows were not new—you did not take them by my leave—your servant asked me to allow you to have a pint of porter, as you were not well—I had never seen you before—I found the things between six and seven o'clock—you were there between one and two.

CAROLINE KING. I live at No. 3, Burley-court, Greenwich. I have known the prisoner five months—on the 30th of Aug., between five and six o'clock, I went to Mrs. Smaill's, and saw the prisoner—she gave me a basket, and asked me to take care of it till she came home—I kept it till between six and seven, and gave it to Henry Chorley—this is it (produced).

HENRY CHORLEY. I live at No. 3, Burley-court, Greenwich. King gave me a basket—I carried it down, and emptied the contents into Mrs. Smaill's apron—there was a china candlestick, a watch-guard, and a pair of bellows—these produced are them.

ELIZABETH SMAILL. I am the wife of Thomas Smaill, of Burely-court, Greenwich. I have known the prisoner about six months—on the 30th of Aug., in the afternoon, the prisoner came to my house—shortly afterwards I received a basket from Chorely—these things produced were in it—the pri
soner was in the house, but was not present.

HENRY BURNS (policeman.) On the afternoon of the 30th of Aug. I ac
companied Mrs. Kreckeler to a house in Burley-court, saw the prisoner, and asked her where the bellows, candlestick, and watch-guard were—she said she had nothing in the world but what she had paid for—I asked where her basket was—she said, behind her—I found it, there was nothing in it—Chorley said in her presence, if I went down stairs he would bring me to where the property was—I went down, and received the articles from Mrs. Smaill—I went back to the prisoner, told her I had found the things, and took her to the station—she said she thought it was better for her to go—I think she had been drinking—she was not drunk then.
(The prisoner produced a written defence stating, that as she wanted the money she had in her pocket, the prosecutrix allowed her to take what she required upon her promising to pay for them.)

GUILTY. Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Two Months
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2227.
GEORGE WELL was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.; I purse, 6d.; 1 bag, 3d. 1 half-sovereign; 3 half-crown; 14 shilling; 1 sixpence; and 4 pence; the property of
George Hat Clarks; having been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH CLARKE. I am the wife of George Hat Clarke—we keep an eating-house and coffee-room. On Monday morning, the 6th of Sept., I was in my shop at Woolwich—I heard a noise in a small room near the street door, looked into it, and saw the prisoner—I asked what he wanted—he said a cup of tea—I told him it was not his place to go there, and accused him of talking something—there had been a bead purse on the table, with 1l. 12s. in it—I shut the door and called my husband—before he came the prisoner dropped a silk handkerchief, which I had left in the cradle behind the door—my husband came—the prisoner said he had not got anything, but afterwards pulled the bag and money out of his right-hand pocket, and put them on the counter.

DANIAL NORTON. I am in the service of Mr. Clarke. On the 6th of Sept. my mistress called me—I saw the prisoner in the shop—he said he had got nothing belonging to my mistress—my master came and my mis
tress asked him where the bag was—he put his hand into his pocket, and put it on the counter—he did not say anything—my master gave him in charge.

SAMUEL WATTS. I am a parish constable. On the 6th of Sept. I took the prisoner—I examined the bag, it contained 14s. 3d.—there was a half-sovereign, one or two sixpences, and a few pence—I searched him, and found four shillings, ten halfpence, and fourpence on him.

THOMAS DAWSON (policeman.) I produced a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—convicted July,1846,confined three weeks, and twice privately whipped: also again convicted at the same session, and con
fined six week, to commerce from the expiration of the first sentence)—I was present at the trials—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined Nine Month.

2228.
RICHARD JACKSON was indicted
for a rape on
Elizabeth Burwill, aged 11 years:—2nd COUNT, unlawfully attempting, &c.

GUILTY on the Second Count. Aged 41.—
confined Two Years.

2229.
ELIZABETH POULTER was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of car
rings, value 1l. 10s.; the goods of
Thomas prince, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy. —
confined One month
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2230.
JOHN NOBLE was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Gilpin, about one in the night of the 1st of Sept., at
St. George the Martyr, Suothwark; with intent to steal.

WILLIAM GILPIN. I live in High-street, Borough, in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark. About eleven o'clock, on the 1st of Sept., I went to bed—I fastened up my premises—the shop-door was bolted and locked—about one o'clock I was awoke by the door-bell ringing—I dressed, went down, and found two constable with the prisoner in custody—I looked round my pre
mises with one of them, and found the first floor back-room window open—there is a court by the side of the house—the window goes out on the leads—the shop extends beyond the house—there is a skylight with leads, and whoever got into the house must have climbed up the water-spout, got on the leads, and then lifted up the back-room window—that could have been done—I found foot-marks on the leads, as if a person had had nails in his boots—it was a scraping on the leads—I had a very large stock—nothing was taken—a pair of steps had been placed against the shop-door at night—I found them two yards from the door, placed against the shutter-box—the window had been shut quite down, but not fastened—I saw the officer pick up a dark lantern in the shop—it was not on my premises before.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Is your dwelling-house at the shop? A. Yes; it is one building—there is only one door in the front, and no door at the back—there was no means of getting in at the back but by the window—when I came down the shop-door was shut, and the policemen were in the shop—there was quite a mob outside, and the police
men closed the door against them—I do not know the prisoner—I always close the window myself—it has a shutter—I had not shut the shutter for some time, but have done so since—I am quite certain I had fastened the window that night—there are gas-light near my shop—the street is very light all through.

DONALD THAIN (policemen, M 246.) On this night I was passing along the Borough, and tried Mr. Gilpin's door to see if it was safe—it opened, and the prisoner rushed out of the shop into the street, and turned to the right toward Union-street—I ran after him—I saw him stopped just as he turned Union-street—I am quite sure the man that was stopped was the man I was in pur
suit of, and I am quite sure the prisoner is the man who came out of the house—I produced a black bag, which I got from Apthorp.

Cross-examined. Q. How far is it from the prosecutor's house to when the prisoner was taken? A. About 130 yards—I lost sight of him for a moment as he turned into Union-street, and then found him in custody— —there was a cry of, "Stop thief!"—people were not running after him—there was a crowd after he was brought back in custody—I saw nobody run after him but myself and Bray—I took him—some more people might have been there—no one was close to him when I took him but Bray—I can
not say whether there were fifteen people within a few yards of him—I saw marks on the lead and window-cill—there was only one mark on the window-ledge—there were a good many on the wall outside—I only saw one at the place where the nails were visible—the wall is a about eleven feet high—the water-spout runs up it—I did not pursue anybody at the back.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Could anybody have been substituted for the prisoner between the time of your missing him for the moment, and turning the corner, and seeing him in the witness's custody? A. No, there was no
body else that could have been mistaken for him.

JESSE BRAY. I am clerk to an attorney, and live in Prince's-road, Ken
nington-cross. About one o'clock on the night in question. I was going along the Borough, and heard a rattle spring—I saw the prisoner running, pursued by the policeman—I did not stop him, but I saw him secured, and am sure he is the man—when he came up to me I stepped off the path, and attempted to stop him, but seeing his arm raised, I had an idea that he had a weapon—I stepped off the path, intending to attack him sideways—he struck at me, and I at him—he passed me, turned the corner, then turned with his face to the wall, and walked back again, as if going towards St. George's church—I did not lose sight of him, and am certain he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. What were you doing out at this time of night? A. I was walking down the Borough, going home—I am in the employ of Mr. Devenport, of Ely-place—I was coming from Tooley-street, where I had been spending the evening with a few friends—I had drank nothing but porter, and not exceeding three pints of that—I have some slight knowledge of having seen the prisoner before, somewhere about the Elephant and Castle—he only turned the corner about three yards—I ran past him for about two yards—I saw nobody in Union-street but the prisoner, Bray, and myself—I went back with him to the prosecutor's—there was a crowd round the door afterwards, but not at the time I came up—a crowd followed us from where we took the prisoner into custody, about ten yards from the corner of Union-street.

WILLIAM APTHORPE. I am a private watchman at the Half Moon in the Borough. I was outside the gate of the Half Moon on the night in question, and saw the prisoner coming towards me, followed by the policeman, hal
loing, "Stop thief!"—I am sure he is the man—I saw him drop the bag produced from under his coat—I picked it up and gave it to the policeman when he came back with the prisoner in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you a watch-box there? A. No, I walk up and down the yard, and sometimes sit down—I had been on duty since nine o'clock—I was standing outside the gate at the time—[it is sleepy work—it is a very light neighbourhood.

WILLIAM PARNELL. (policeman, M 5.) I saw the prisoner in company with two others, in the neighbourhood of Blackman-street, Borough, between half-past four or five o'clock on the afternoon in question—I am quite certain he is the person—he was only a short distance from the prosecutor's house—they were walking along together in the direction of St. George's church—I did not see him again till next morning.

Cross-examined. Q. Then you saw him in custody? A. Yes, in the cells—they were not walking in a direction towards the Surrey Theatre, but coming from it—I was going towards it—I met no other parties that after
noon that took my notice—I was not examined before the Magistrate.
DAVID HANSELL (policeman, M 117.) I was on the spot, and picked up this lantern in Mr. Gilpin's shop, about two yards from the door.
MR. GILPIN re-examined. This is not my lantern—it was not there over night.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 26.—
Confined One Year.

2231.
THOMAS SULLIVAN and
CHARLES SMITH were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Alfred Brown, about the hour of five in the night of the 30th of Aug., and stealing therein 1 watch, value 1l. 10s.; 2 spoons, 5s.; 1 pair of sugar-tongs, 6d.; 2 handker
chiefs, 4s.; 1 hat, 12s.; 523 pence and 420 halfpence, his property; and 1 pair of spectacles, value 4s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Brown; they having been before convicted of felony: to which

SULLIVAN pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 21.

SMITH pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 22.

2232.
JANE HEWITT was indicted
for stealing 42 yards of cotton, value 1l. 3s.; the goods of
Richards Heman.

RICHARD HEMAN. I am a linen-draper, of Albion-terrace, Wandsworth On the 18th of Sept., about eleven o'clock at night, I missed a piece of cot
ton print—I had seen it safe ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before—I accompanied the policeman to the prisoner's lodgings, found her there, and the print also—this produced is it—she said she did not take it herself—I have a piece which was torn off the print, it corresponds with it.
Prisoner. Q. Have not I been at the shop a number of times?. A. I do not recollect, but it is very possible.

WILLIAM BARNARD. I am in Mr. Heman's service. On Saturday night about eleven o'clock, I was five or six yards from the door, and saw the prisoner come out to the door three or four times, and then go away very quickly.

EDWARD WIDDELL (policeman.) On Saturday night, between ten and eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner about 100 yards from Mr. Hemman's shop passing and repassing for an hour—I received information, and went with Mr. Heman to her lodging—I knew she lived there by seeing her them—I saw her, and told her she was suspected of stealing a piece of cotton print from Mr. Heman, and asked if she had any objection to my searching—she said, "No"—I searched, and found this cotton under the bed.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
2233.
MARY ANN WALLS was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged acquittance and receipt for the payment of 1s. 2d., with intent to defraud
James Aldridge.

JAMES ALDRIDGE. The prisoner came into my service on the 2nd of June—I gave her money every week to pay the small tradesmen in the neighbourhood—I know Mr. Males, the beer-shop keeper—this now produced is a bill of his—I gave the prisoner the money to pay it—she returned me the bill receipted the same night or the next morning, and I put it on the file.

COURT. Q. What directions did you give her when you gave her the money? A. I laid the money for each bill upon it, and told her to go and pay each tradesman immediately—she went away, and afterwards brought me this receipt—(read—"June 27,847; Mr. Aldridge to Hugh Males, week's beer, 1s. 2d. Received, Hugh Males.")

HUGH MALES. I keep a beer-shop. This is a bill supplied to the prosecutor—it is in my hand-writing, with the exception of the receipt—that is not mine—I never authorized any person to put my name to that bill—it has not been paid.

COURT. Q. Had you ever received money from the prisoner? A. I have, about once, two months ago—my wife attends to my business in my absence, but never receipts any bills—she can write, but this is not her writing.

(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that she was induced by the prosecutor to live with him as his wife; that, instead of paying the bills weekly, she was in the habit of letting them accumulate till they amounted to 10s. or 12s.; when she discharged them, and that she intended paying the bill in question on the day following her being taken into custody.)

JEMES ALDRIDGE
re-examined. What the prisoner states is entirely false—I never had any familiar intercourse with her—she said would makes up this story for me and the rest of the witnesses.

GUILTY. Aged 41.—
Confined Two Years.
(There were several other indictments against the prisoner.)

2234.
THOMAS SIMPSON was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Alfred Lainson, putting him in fear, and taking from his person and against his will, I half-crown. 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences, his monies; and
MARY GREEN
as an accessary before the fact.

ALRFED LAINSON. I am a carpenter, and live at 45, Portman-street, Vauxhall. On Saturday evening, the 21st of Aug., about twenty minutes to nine o'clock, I was in Battersea-fields, and overtook the prisoner Green—she spoke to me first, and said, "My dear, will you go with me"?—I told her, "No, I was going home"—I had never seen her before—I bade her good night—I did not stop, I merely turned round and walked on again—a boy then came up to me, crying, and saying he had lost a horse—I stopped to speak to him, and Green ran away—the prisoner Simpson then ran up to me, and said I had been with his wife, and if I did not give him something he would punch my head off, and he put himself in a fighting attitude—I told him I had not been with his wife, or any man's wife, and I would not give him anything—he put his fingers up to his mouth and whistled—I then saw several men running towards me from the tents in the field, and I ran away—they set a dog at me—in running away I stumbled over a mound and fell—Simpson then came up to me, and the other men also—there were about eight or twelve of them—I directly jumped up—he com
plained to the other men that I had been with his wife, and they all said I must give them some money—Simpson touched my waistcoat, and he and another man held out their hands, and said I must give them some money—I asked them to go to a public-house with me, and I would treat them with drink—I proposed that with a view of identifying some of them—they all said, "No, that will not do for us, you must give us the money now"—Simpson and another man then held out their hands, and I gave them half-a
crown each—they then told me to go away from the field and never come there any more—I gave them the money out of fear—they threatened to punch my head if I did not—I went straight towards Battersea-bridge, met a policeman, and returned with him to the spot—we saw the prisoner Green in the Old-House-at-Home public-house in the field, but I did not speak to her—I had not taken any sort of liberty with the girl, or anybody else.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. This was somewhere about nine o'clock? A About twenty minutes to nine o'clock—it was about a quarter to nine o'clock when I met the policeman, and that was about five

minutes after this matter happened—it was dusk, getting dark—it was a moonlight night—there are no gas-lights in Battersea-fields—I saw Simpson on the Sunday following, the next day, in the field—I did not give him into custody, the policeman was too far behind, and he made his escape—I was in search of him with the policeman—I saw him in the field, putting stumps down in the booth—he walked very fast, and I missed him while I was looking after the policeman—I saw him again on the 2nd of Sept., when he was taken into custody—I was taken to the station by a policeman, to see him—he was pointed out to me—I was not at all drunk on the night in question.

COURT. Q. How far was Simpson from you when you saw him in the field on the Sunday? A. Within a yard or two—there is a fair held there on Sundays—I saw him scarcely for a minute—he went into the booth, and out at the other end—he saw me, and appeared to know me—he coloured is the face, and while I was making a sign to the policeman he disappeared—I am quite sure he saw me—the policeman was about 100 yards behind me, coming across the field—I communicated this to the policeman as soon as I got up to him.

Green. How can you say he was putting stumps in the booth when I was down there on the very same Sunday evening, and he had cock-shy sticks in his hand? Witness. They were stumps—I did not see you in the field that day—I did not give you any money.

THOMAS BENT (policeman V 95.) I heard of this robbery on the Tuesday, and looked for the prisoner Simpson—I saw him on Thursday, the 2nd of Sept., in the Wandsworth-road—I asked whether he did not go by the name of Swanney—he said he did—I said he was charged with robbing a man in Bat
tersea-fields on the Saturday night week before—he said. "I was not them at all that night"—I said I must take him to the station to see whether he was or not—I had known him before by the name of Thomas Simpson, and by the nickname of Swanney.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he say, "I was not there that night; I was not near the place?" A. Yes.

JHON WALLIS (policeman, V 293.) I was on duty in Battersa-foelds on the evening of the 21st of Aug., and about five minutes before nine o'clock met the prosecutor—he told me what had happened to him, in consequence of which I went back with him—we saw the female prisoner, but I did not speak to her or take her into custody then—I saw her again on the 3rd of Sept., and took her into custody—I told her she was charged with being concerned in a robbery in Battersea-fields with Swanney Simpson—she said she knew nothing about Swanney Simpson—next day, after coming out of the Magis
trate's office, she said there was only her and Simpson and the prosecutor there, only them three—no one was putting questions to her at that time—she was in custody at the time—we were returning from the Magistrate's office—she said she wanted to give her evidence—I told her she had been asked twice whether she had anything to ask the witnesses, and she had said as—she said she wished to tell the truth, that there was only them three there, that was Simpson, her, and the prosecutor.

Cross-examined. Q. Only three, where? A. In Battersea-fields, at the time of the robbery—I believe "there" was the word she used—I am sure that was the word—"there at the time"—I was only examined once before the Magistrate, that was on the same day that Green was examined—what she said was on coming away from the examination—she had been remanded from the day before, for her and Simpson to be brought up together.

COURT. Q. Were you before the Magistrate more than once? A. Yes—I was there after Green stated this to me—I made a mistake when I said I was only examined once before the Magistrate—I was examined twice—it was the second time that she said what I have stated.

Green. I never said whether there were three or four persons. Witness. She did, and the prosecutor heard her as well—she said she wished t tell the truth, that there was only Simpson and her and the prosecutor there at the time—I swear she said that, and she heard me state it to the Magistrate.

JOHN POTTER (policeman, V 118.) On the night of the 21st of Aug. I was on duty in Battersea-fields, and saw Simpson there about a quarter-past eight o'clock—I knew him, and had seen him there the whole of the season—he has got cock-shies there—I have seen Green about there with a number of other persons, stopping out there—there is a kind of fair there the whole of the summer, with horse-riding, swings, target-shooting, with nuts, and all that kind of thing.

WILLIAM JOHNSON. I keep a coffee-stall in Battersea-fields. I know the prisoners by sight, but nothing more—I have not been there long—I begun to keep the stall about two months ago, and have seen them in my stall every day for the last two months, sometimes apart and sometimes together.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen Green with other men? A. No, not unless they were in company together—I have not seen Simpson with other people—I never noticed him, except in her company—if she came for any refreshment when he was down in field, she had it and went away—sometimes they both came together.

COURT. Q. You have seen a good many other people in these fields during the two months? A. Yes, hundreds of the same rank in life—it was nothing particular to see him there on the 21st of Aug., more than any one else—I was at home, no board my barge in the dock in Battersea-fields on Saturday night, at nine o'clock—I did not know anything about this till Monday.
MR. RYLAND. Q. What time did you give up business in your stall? A. About nine o'clock—the stall is in the barge—I live there.

ALFRED LAINSON
re-examined. I was in the girl's company about a minute and a half or two minutes—I did not look at her before she spoke to me, or look round at her as I passed—I was turning my head round, and was just about walking on, when the boy came up to me—he was crying very bitterly, which attracted my attention—when he ran away, she ran away too, and the men ran towards me—I had not much opportunity of looking at her face, but I knew her again directly I saw her—I had never seen her before—I saw her again the same evening—it was all done in three, four, or five minutes—the male prisoner whistled almost directly he came up—he stood facing me, in a fighting attitude—the moon was shining, and I could distinguish his countenance well—I had seen him as I was crossing the field, in the early part of the evening, in company with another man, and recol
lected, having seen him before that day—I am quite satisfied he is the same person.

THOMAS BENT
re-examined. I was before the Magistrate on the 8th, when the prisoners made a statement—they were asked severally whether they had anything to say—Green made a statement, which was taken down, and read over to her—she made her mark, and the Magistrate signed it—I know his writing—Simpson also made a short statement, which was witnessed by the Magistrate.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear Wallis examined? A. Yes, on the 4th—I apprehended Green on the 3rd—to the best of my belief, he went through the whole of his examination again on the 8th—I might not have been there the whole of the day—I gave no evidence that day—I have no doubt I was there the whole of the time—I was there at the time the deposi
tion were read—I do not think I left the Court at all—I believe I went out once with the male prisoner—the examination was not going on then—I do not think I was called out of Court—I heard Wallis make his statement—he gave the whole of his evidence on the 8th—I do not remember what evidence he gave—the prisoners were told that they might say what they liked, but what they said would be taken down and used against or for them at the trial—Mr. Beadon was the Magistrate—I have seen him write many times for two or three months—I stood close to him, and saw him write this—I know the character of his writing—I have seen him sign my recognisance papers—I should say this is not his writing (looking at a paper)—I will not swear to it—I have not seen him write like that—I have a doubt about this being his writing—he sometimes writes similar to this, but not like this—he writes "William Frederic Beadon," but not with a lot of dashes under it—(The prisoners' statements were here read—"The prisoner Green says, 'On last Saturday fortnight, between seven and eight o'clock, the gentleman met me and asked me how I did, and asked me to take his arm—he went with me to the Red House, and treated me—we went across the fields—he said he had taken a fancy to me, and he would be a good friend to me, but he was rather short of cash that night, that he had only 3s. 6d. in his waistcoat pocket—he gave me 3s., and said he would keep the 6d., as we should want a glass of brandy-and-water—he took me across the bank, and began taking indecent liberties with me—I would not let him—he wanted me to give him the money back—I said it was a gift, but I would go to a house with him—he said he would knock me down if I did not let him do as he liked—I said, 'If you do, I shall get somebody to do it for you'—he struck me on the shoul
der—I called out, and Simpson ran from the booth—I told him, and he told the gentleman he had better go on about his business, and he went on—I went on, and saw the prosecutor fall down over the bank—I went to the Old House-at-Home, and treated Simpson for his protection—I asked him to see me across the fields—he saw me as far as the Duchess public-house, and left me—I saw the gentleman on the Tuesday after, and because I would not let him go with me, he said he would punish me and the man too—The prisoner Simpson says, 'What she has said is true, he never gave me any money.' ")
(Thomas Holden, plumber, of New Compton-street, Soho, gave Simpson a good character.)

SIMPSON—
GUILTY. Aged 21.

GREEN—
GUILTY. Aged 18.

2235.
RICHARD HAYNES was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Jane M'Casland, and wounding her, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

JANE M'CASLAND. I live with my mother, Susan M'Casland, at 29, Lant-street, Southwark. On the 26th of July, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Mint-street, going to get a jug of hot water, and saw the prisoner leading a woman along—he was not drunk, but the woman was—I

passed, and turned round to look at them—I did not speak to them—the pri
soner dropped the person he was carrying, and ran up and kicked me in the bottom of my belly—I cannot recollect whether he said anything, for I lost my senses, and fell into a gentleman's arms—I did not recollect myself till I found myself in my mother's bed—I have been confined to my bed ever since.

Prisoner. Q. What did you say when I had hold of my mother? A. I did not speak to you—I did not say you had kicked your mother—I did not know you had done so—I am quite sure I did not speak to you or interfere.

CHARLES SOMERVILLE. I am a porter, in the Borough-market, and live in Mint-street. On Sunday evening, the 25th of July, about half-past eight o'clock, I was in Mint-street, right opposite out door, and saw the prisoner assault the prosecutrix—she fell into my arms—the prisoner was leading his mother in his arms along the road, about five yards from me, and the children sat up a hooting, seeing her drunk—the prosecutrix was coming along with an empty jug in her hand—the prisoner was coming one way, and she the other—the prisoner stood still, and she looked him in the face, but never said a word—in about a minute, he said, "If you don't get out of the way, you young b----, I will kick your guts out of you," and he no sooner said that than he dropped his mother on the pavement; ran towards the girl directly, and kicked her at the same moment—I went to assist her—she was about five yards from me—I caught her in my arms, if I had not, she would have dropped on the kerb-stone, and cut her head open—she was in a fainting state—I got a man to assist me, and took her home.

COURT. Q. Did you say there were other children there? A. Yes, several—they were hooting at him before the girl came up—they were laughing and hallooing at seeing a drunken woman—she was so drunk that it was a sight to see her—she could not stand—the children were not all together—this girl was quite by herself, with the jug in her hand—she was on this side, against a shop, more in the gutter—the other children were more across the road, making a noise—she did not say a word, or do anything, that I observed—I should have seen or heard her if she had—she was about five yards from me, and four yards from the prisoner—when he had kicked her, he ran away directly, and left his mother to herself.

Prisoner. My mother was solid and sober; it was me that was tipsy. Witness. His mother was quite drunk—he had had a little drop, but was perfectly conscious of what he did—he ran away directly—it happened right opposite my door—I did not see him come from the public-house, or where he came from—it was not done opposite the public-house, but opposite the chandler's shop, on the left-hand side of the public-house, three or four doors from it.

Prisoner. If you stood there, you must have heard the words the girl made use of; but you were not there, you were at your door, and I was at the public-house, and there are five or six doors between. Witness. No, only three—it was right facing my door—I am quite sure she did not speak a word to you.

CHRISTIANA EDENEY. I am wife of Edward Edeney, of Mint-street. On Sunday evening, the 25th of July, I saw the prisoner in the road with a woman, and the prosecutrix going for some water—the mug was standing before her—the prisoner laid his mother down in the road, the girl was standing before her, he made use of a very bad expression, kicked her at the bottom of the belly, and told her to be off—she fell back, and would have
fallen on the kerb-stone had not Somerville caught her—I saw her takes home—I followed her, and saw a deal of blood on her clothes—I was there when the doctor examined her.

COURT. Q. Did you hear the children hooting at the prisoner? A. No, they were kicking up a great noise before this happened—I did not hear the girl say anything, she was only looking on—I am quite sure she did not say a word, nor was she making any noise—she was not with the children who were making a noise—she was going past, and was going to turn to look at the woman on the ground.

Prisoner. Q. Where were you? A. Against my own door—I lodge there—that is the statement I made to Mr. Cottingham—I said I was op
posite Mr. Shea's house, not that lived there—I did not wish to say where I lived, because I knew I should be annoyed by the people that lived in the house—I said it was immaterial where I lived, I lived just by there.

GEORGE ELISHA NEWTH. I am a surgeon, and live in Great Suffolk-street. On the 20th of July I was called to attend the prosecutrix—I found her lying on the bed, very faint—I examined her person, and found that the bottom of her belly, in the * * *, it was a wound about an inch and a half long, and was bleeding very much—there was a wound and a bruise—there was a good deal of blood on her person—in my opinion, it was a dangerous wound—she is suffering from it now very much—the bladder was very much affected, and is now—as soon as she came to, she complained of very great pain at the bottom of the belly, great pain on pressure—I administered proper remedies—she is has complained more or less since of that pain—she at first suffered from not passing her water, but now she has great difficulty in holding it, and has great pain when she passes it—she feels much easier when she is in a recumbent posture—she has been confined to her bed up to this time—in my opinion, such a contusion and wound might have been caused by the kick of a powerful man—if it had been a little higher, it might have ruptured the bladder—she is certainly recovering now, but I expect she will feel the effect of it almost ever after.

COURT. Q. When you say there was a wound, do you mean to say that the skin was broken? A. Yes—I am quite sure it amounted to a wound—it bled—it could not have bled without the skin breaking—it must have been a very violent kick.

Prisoner. Q. You told Mr. Cottingham it was not much of a wound, and not near the bottom of the belly, and that very trifling blood ran from it? A. I never said anything of the kind—the Magistrate said if there was any danger to her life I was to get further opinion, that the prisoner might have the benefit of all the medical advice that could be obtained, because, if the girl died, he perhaps might be committed for murder; but as the girl was getting better the mother did not wish anybody else called in.
WILLIAM GRIST (policeman, M 223.) I took the prisoner, and produce one of his boots—it has large nails in it—he said he was going into the country to work, and knew nothing about it.

SUSAN M'CASLAND. I am the prosecutrix's mother. On the 25th of July I sent her for a mug of pump water—she was quite well when she went—she was brought home senseless—she has been confined to her bed ever since, and hardly able to sit up more than a few minutes in the course of the day.
Prisoner. Q. Was not she at Mr. Sutton's funeral? A. No, she was in bed.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in a public-house drinking with some parties;

my mother came, and said "Come home, and get your supper, because you must go to work early in the morning, and are three-parts drunk now;" I said if I came home I should lose a day's work, and asked her to go home and cook my victuals for me; she did so, and came back for me; I called for a glass of rum; as we came out somebody struck her; she told me of it, and I went out to find who it was; I wanted to get her home, and she went off in a fit; I could not get her on; this wench comes up, and said, "That man has kicked his mother;" I said, "My lady, the best thing you can do is to go away, and don't keep cheeking me;" she kept on saying, "That is the man that kicked his mother;" I took off my cap, and hit her with it; she did not offer to move, and I up with my foot, and kicked her jug.

MARY ANN BROWN. Eight weeks ago last Sunday I saw the prisoner intoxicated several times in the course of the day—at half-past seven in the evening I went into a public-house, where the prisoner and his mother were, for a pint of beer—I saw him at the bar persuading his mother to go home—they were both intoxicated a good deal.

GUILTY of a Common Assault. Aged 28.—
Confired Six Months.

2235.
JOHN SAUNDERS was indicted
for stealing 1 sheep, value 1l. 18s.; the property of
John Charles Watson.

WILLIAM LYNES (policeman R 238.) On Wednesday, the 25th of Aug., I was in a field near Nunhead Cemetery, Deptford—I was dressed in a dark coat, not in my uniform—May, another officer, was with me in plain clothes—I got into a field, and found the prisoner skinning a sheep at the further corner, about a yard from the hedge—he was standing up with a knife in his hand, and the sheep between his legs—I said, "It is a fine night"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Are you skinning the sheep?"—he said, "Yes—I said, "You are not much hand at skinning a sheep"—he said, "No"—I said, "Lend me the knife"—he asked me if I was a good hand at skinning a sheep—I said, "Yes, I have skinned and dressed a good many for Mr. Covel, of Lewisham; I was two years at it"—he said, "I think I shall be able to manage it"—I said, "Put the knife down, and take hold of the skin, and pull it towards the head, it will come off"—he did not put down the knife, but he took hold of the skin, pulled it up towards the head, and it came off as far as the neck—he then cut the head off, and put the knife down—I then stepped on the knife, took hold of him by the collar, and told him I was a policeman in plain clothes—May took hold of him at the same time—he tried to make his escape from us—with a deal of trouble we tied his hands together, and took him to the station—when I took him, he said he had found the sheep dying and stuck it; that he had a large family, and was out of employment—he had a steel with him—the sheep was quite warm—I suppose it was stuck about seven minutes before I came up—there was a quantity of blood about a yard form the sheep—I put my hand on the blood, it was quite warm—the prisoner had two rush baskets with him, and two or three towels in them, a hoe laid close by him—there was a bruise on the sheep's head from a blow—there were more sheep in the field—there was no public footpath in the field—I took the sheep to Mr. Allaway, a butcher, at Deptford, and he dressed it—I took the skin and head with me to the station-house—the skin was pro
duced before the Magistrate.
Prisoner. Q. You asked me what I was going to do with it. A. I did
not; you said it was dying when you stuck it—there have been three sheep slaughtered besides this, and one taken away.
MAY (policeman, R 296.) I have heard Lynes' evidence—it is correct—I was near enough to hear all that passed.

CHARLES WATSON. I am a butcher, in Kendall-street, Old Kent-road—I turned out fifteen sheep into a field of Mr. Cheshire's, about the 2nd of Aug., I afterwards took eight to be slaughtered, seven remained in the field on the night in question—I heard of the prisoner's being found in the field, about one or two that same morning—the two policemen came and informed me—next day I went to the field, and one of the sheep was missing—there were only six there—I went to Mr. Allaway's that same day, and there saw the carcase—I identified the skin at the station-house that same day—this now produced is it—it has the same mark that I put on all my sheep, the wool is just the same, and the brand mark "P"—I believe it to be the skin of one of my sheep—it was a Kent wether sheep, worth 38s.—I went into the field, and saw some blood by the side of the ditch in the corner by the hedge, as if the sheep had been stuck there.

Prisoner's Defence.
