The hoe I took with the intention of getting work is turnip-fields; the basket I intended to sell, and had been to two or three pawnbrokers with it, but they would not buy it; I was going home at night, and got lost; I went up this place to lie down, it appeared to me like a wood, there being trees there; the sheep laid in the ditch; I felt it, it was warm; I made no more to do, but cut its head off, which I had done to many a one before, though not for the same purpose; I lived with a gentleman who bought upwards if 20,000 a year, and he always told me whenever I found a sheep that had been dead some hours to cut its head off; if I had not been in a state of starvation I should not have done it; I had been two or three days without anything for my children; I know I was wrong in so doing; I had not had any meat for upwards of a month, and for eight weeks not above a pound; still I did not kill the sheep, neither did I steal it, and my intention was to take part of it at a time; it was impossible for me, in the weak state I was, to catch a sheep, neither is there one butcher's man in twenty that can do it.

GUILTY. Aged 41.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2236.
JOHN AUGUSTUS OLDS was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Mary Olds; He was also charged upon the Coroner's Inquisition with the like manslaughter.

FREDERICK RICHARD GOWAR. I am a surgeon, in the Old Kent-road. I knew the deceased Mrs. Olds very well—I was called to see her on the Thursday, the day she died—I had attended her before, for violet cough, occasional spitting of blood, and irritability of the lungs—it was a pulmonary complaint—my first observation of her on this occasion was on the Wednesday morn
ing, 25th of Aug., when she came to my house, and complained of violent pain in her chest and about the stomach, and vomiting of blood at times—while she was in my house she spat up a good deal of blood—I never knew her spit blood before—she had frequently complained of cough and cold—she complained of being hurt about the throat, and being held and pressed about the chest—I saw the throat—the skin appeared a little reddened, as if com
pressed, but there was nothing particularly marked about it—it seemed redder

than it ought to be—there were no bruises—it was only red in one part—the left temple was bruised—that seemed to have been the effect of some violence—it was rather a lasting bruise, but not of itself likely to occasion death—I prescribed for her, and directed her to take everything very cold—I was sent for to her the next day, between one and two o'clock, and she was dead—I was prevented from seeing her in the morning—there was venous blood about the mouth—it seemed to come from the lungs—it was of a dark colour—by the direction of the Coroner I made a post-mortem examination—the appearance of the lungs was very unhealthy—the upper part of each lung was very congested, very loaded with extravasated blood, the bronchial vessels also very loaded with blood and the aesophagus—the blood in the lungs was partly fluid and partly coagulated—the liver was very unhealthy, of a very dark colour instead of its natural colour—there was a flaxidity about it, which showed a great deal of unnatural character—the gall-bladder was almost empty—there was scarcely any bile in it—it contained a little air apparently—the stomach appeared partially inflamed about the upper part, and there was a great deal of blood mixed with fluid of the stomach—it must have come into the stomach from the trachea—the vessels were very loaded with blood, not rup
tured, but the arteries of that part are so minute, in all probability the blood might have come in partially from the veins of the stomach—that would not account for the whole—a large quantity must have come from the lungs, and got down the throat—the spleen and other organs were not quite healthy—there did not appear any inflammation about the bowels in general—the principal seat of disorder appeared the lungs and liver, and the irregular state of the bladder—in my opinion the flow of blood from the lungs arose from violence by blows or falls—the lungs being in a weak state they were susceptible—I can undertake to say that violence must have produced those effects—they could not have been produced to that extent without violence.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long had you attended this poor woman? A. Several times in the course of the summer—she had taken medicine—she had stated to me before this that she had spit small quantities of blood, not to any extent—she told me that she occasionally expectorated blood—I mean by that, thrown it from her lungs—that might probably be occasioned by ulceration—there must have been some lesion of ves
sels to give rise to it—there may be a lesion without a rupture, or the evacuation of blood, but it generally happens—I am able to say that the blood evacuated was venous blood, and not arterial—I did not ascertain what vessel was broken—there were a variety of vessels, towards the upper part of the lungs, not any of the main vessels—there is no difficulty in ascertaining whether blood is venous or arterial—the colour of venous blood is dark, and arterial blood is red or florid—at the upper part of the lungs, the veins and arteries mix and inter
sect—I can hardly say that there were no arterial vessels ruptured, probably there might have been, but the greater amount was venous blood—I cannot say whether that was from the diseased part of the lung, as the lungs alto
gether were very weak, and participated in point of texture to a similarity of construction—there had been ulceration—it occasionally happens with the lungs in such a state, that the cough may rupture the vessels and produce great extravasation of blood—it is almost universally the mode in which such patients die—I know that the deceased was subject to a frequent cough—I do not consider, from the appearances of the lungs, that a violent fit of coughing would have produced the great effusion that I witnessed; the lungs were apparently not in that very tender state as to produce it—they were in a weakened state—external violence must be a considerably greater strain

upon the lungs than a cough—it must in my opinion have been done by a violent concussion which jarred the vessels, and gave rise to the ruptures—such a concussion might be occasioned by a violent cough under a very much more diseased state of lings, but I do not consider these lungs were in that state—none of the main vessels were ruptured, only the smaller once—they would be very tender, and were in a delicate state.

Q. Suppose she had died from any other cause than the rupture, and you had seen these lungs without the extravasation of blood upon them, should you have said they were at all safe even from day to day? A. Yes—I should not consider they were in such a weak state as to give way—I should not consider that a violent cough would have been likely to affect them at all

Q. Evan though you had heard that she had been in the habit of spiting blood? A. The answer to that question would depend entirely upon the examination of any particular part which might be diseased—I believe har age was about forty odd, I cannot say exactly, from forty to fifty—she might have been fifty-two—the blood in the stomach had come from the lungs, got into the trachea, and so passed into the stomach.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Do I understand you rightly, that the state of the lungs was not in your opinion such as to lead you to conclude that a mere fit of coughing would have ruptured the vessels, and have produced the quantity of blood you saw? A. Yes—if on the Saturday night pre
vious to my seeing her, she had been thrown down on the ground, and held there, I should consider that would account for the rupture of the vessels I saw.

COURT. Q. Were there many ulcers on the lungs? A. Not a great many, there were four or five patches of ulceration—sometimes the efflux of blend arises from ulceration eating into the vessels, opening the surface of the vessels themselves; and sometimes a vessel will burst or rupture from con
cussion, by reason of its weakness—it was quite impossible for me to in
vestigate the number of opening through which the blood might have flowed, there was such a large accumulation in the parts that it was nothing but a mass of blood, intermixed so firmly in the upper part of the lungs with the trachea, and so on, that it was a complete choak as it were—I divided the lungs in my examination, but could discriminate the openings, the vessels are so very minute there—suffocation was the immediate cause of death by the vomiting of blood into the mouth, choaking the passage—she was cough
ing at the time she came to me in the morning from the quantity of blood that was rising in her throat—I had never seen her so violently troubled by a cough before—I had seen her about a fortnight before—I did not observe any more chance of her dying then, than I had observed at other periods when I had seen her—if I had heard next morning that she had been taken with a violent cough which had ended in suffocation by blood, I should have been very much surprised—she was not in that condition—she was generally emaciated, with weak powers, and had been in a bad state of health for several years—there was no accounting for the state of the liver, lungs, spleen, and gall-bladder—there was peculiar constitutional irregularity—I had know her for many years, and she was a very regular, quiet, domestic person—the liver may be disordered by a habit of drinking—there were appearances that would arise from irregular habits, but I never saw her intoxicated, or sup
posed she was addicted to drinking—I always considered her a woman of feeble habits, weak about the lungs, with an unnatural state of liver, and no on—the ordinary immediate cause of death from pulmonary complaints is from inflammation of the substance of the lungs, producing matter, so that

they expectorate pus and in proportion to the number of ulcers on the sur
face of the lungs, so in the same ratio will a person become sooner or later destroyed—it is a diminution of the powers of life—the process of ulcera
tion going on in the lungs must necessarily furnish blood to support those inflammatory parts, and thus nature is robbed of a very great support—it decays the functions of the lungs—I examined the deceased's body externally—I did not perceive any marks of violence except that on the left temple and the throat.

LOUISA WILCOXON. I am the wife of Henry Wilcoxon, a brush-maker, living at 1, Wood's-court, John-street, Newington—I knew the deceased Mrs. Olds and her husband, they lived in the next house to me. On the Saturday night the 21st Aug., I was in my own back room, and was disturbed by a fall, and a cry of murder—I heard the fall first—the deceased and her husband slept in the up-stairs front room—the fall appeared to be in their back room—I heard Mrs. Olds cry "Murder"—I then ran to my door and opened it—the cries were still going on—they then appeared to come from the front room—I went up stairs into my front room, and opened the window, and then heard Mr. Olds say something to his wife, but what it was I could not understand—I heard her crying—I did not hear her say anything—it appeared to me as though he was still beating her—I did not see him—I judged by her cries that he was beating her—I did not hear the sound of blows just then—I saw their son William pass my door as I opened it—he came from his father's house—I saw him come back with a policeman—after the policeman was gone, I heard Mr. Olds beating his wife again—I heard the blows—the policeman stayed, I should think, about five minutes—I heard Mrs. Olds say, "You brute," you brute," several times, that was after I heard the sound of blows—there was no one there but the boy William, Mr. Olds, and his wife—I only heard the one fall, the other was hitting—I saw the deceased about four o'clock on the afternoon of the next day (the Sunday) in the back yard—she was very ill then—I saw her again on the Monday in the back yard, and saw marks on her throat—I did not see them on Sunday—I was nearer to her on Monday than I was on the Sunday—she had a bruise on the left temple—I had seen her about the middle of the day on the satur
day—she had not any bruise on the left temple then—I was her on the Wednesday and Thursday—she was very ill each day—each day she got worse—I saw her at the sink vomiting blood—she called me to see it—I had not seen her spit blood before the Saturday—she had not been well for some time before—after the Saturday night I observed a very great change in her—it continued up to Thursday, when she died—I saw her on the morning she died, at nine o'clock, not after that—she died at half-past two—I ran in when she was dying.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you intimate with her? A. Yes—I generally saw her every day—she used to go out washing I believe—she did not go out to wash after this, and had not been for some weeks before, in consequence of the state of her heath—she said she had no strength—she appeared not well—she had a very bad cough—it was a very teasing cough, lasting for some minutes at a time—it appeared to strain her and try her very much—I did not see that she spat blood when she coughed—I have seen her spit after the coughing, but have not noticed whether there was—blood or not—it did not seem to be matter—she was a very sober woman—I never saw her the worse for liquor—I heard the prisoner say something to her, but what it was I could not understand—he was tipsy—when he was tipsy I could not understand him—he was tipsy on Saturday night.

MR. GOWAR re-examined. Hemorrhage on the lungs produced by violence does not diminish in general—I never knew it do so—if the violence was great I should think it likely that the hemorrhage would continue; but there are so many shades, it depends entirely upon the degree of violence, and the injury occasioned by that violence—in this instance it seemed to increase, under a cer
tain state it would diminish—the natural tendency would be to heal—I do not consider the blow on the temple likely to have produced this hemorrhage—I attribute the redness of the neck to squeezing—that alone was not sufficient to occasion the hemorrhage, nor do I consider that the two combined were sufficient—there was no evident mark of any blow, or pressure, or violent impact on the head—there was extravasation about the neck and shoulder, resulting from the following of the blood from the lungs, but that was from the position of the body after death—if she was seized by the throat, and forced violently upon the ground, I think that might have produced the mischief, by a violent jarring of the system—if that might were so, it would be natural to ex
pect to find some mark on the back, but I saw none, nor any bruise—a per
son might be pushed down, and receive a violent inward shock, without any external appearance of it whatever—I cannot say that the same concussion would be produced, if in a struggle she fell down, as if she had been thrown down and pressed upon—I found nothing to indicate that she had been cut down and passed upon.

ELIZA OLDS. I am the wife of Joseph Olds, a bricklayer, and live at No. 3, John-street, next door to the prisoner; I married his son. On the satur
day night before the deceased's death I heard a piece of work there—the youngest boy, William, came to me; and, in consequence of what he said I went in—I found the prisoner and the deceased there alone—the deceased opened the door the moment I got there, and the prisoner shut it again—the deceased went towards the door again—the prisoner would not let her open it—he took her round the waist, and she fell down—she desired me to open the window—I jumped on the table to open it, and Mr. Palmer jumped in at the window—he lives in the same street—my mother was then on the floor by the front door, and my father by her—I do not know whether he had hold of her or not—in my fright I did not see—I do not know how she got on the floor—she was not on the floor when I jumped on the table to open the win
dow, but when I opened it and Mr. Palmer jumped in, she was, and the prisoner had hold of her, I did not see in what way—Mr. Palmer went away before I did—I remained with the deceased—my husband came in, and took the pri
soner away—he was gone about an hour and a half—I had not seen the de
ceased on the Friday—I had seen her on the Thursday—I was with her on the Sunday—she did not appear to be very well then—she complained of being very stiff and sore—she was up, and down stairs on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, and on the Thursday also—she seemed as if she got very weak and had—she had been very ill for a long time, and getting worse—she had been getting weaker and weaker every day up to this times—she got worse and worse from the Sunday till the Thursday—she died about half-past two o'clock on the Thursday—she was choked, through vomiting blood—I went for the doctor, but she was dead before he came—the prisoner was quite tipsy on the Saturday night.

Cross-examined. Q. While you were in the room, you did not see your father strike your mother at all? A. No, I did not see any blows—I did not see him use any violence at all towards her while I was there—she did not call out as if any violence was used towards her, but I did not come up till it was over—when the deceased was on the ground I do not know whether the

prisoner was trying to help her up or not—I had observed the deceased spit
ting during the last eight or nine months, and every time she spat she spat blood—that had been increasing—she said she spat more every day, I did not see it—I had seen her spit blood before this Sunday, but not that quantity that she did at last—I saw her spit blood on the Monday night—I do not know whether she did so on the Saturday—I did not see her till the Saturday night—I saw her spit a little on the Sunday—she spat more blood on the Monday than she had done before—not a great deal more—I had never seen her spit so much before—the prisoner was almost always very kind to her, and to me and the rest of the family, for whatever I saw.

MR. PAYNE. Q. You did not live with him? A. No Monday night, and—I did not see the deceased at the sink on the Monday—I saw her on the saw her spit blood in the fire-place—I had seen her spit blood before the Saturday—she mostly spat it as she sat by the fire-place—there was mostly phlegm with it—I never saw anything like what occurred on the day she died, or like what occurred on the Monday night.

COURT. Q. Was it worse on Monday than it was on Sunday. A. Yes; it was getting worse every day, and on the Thursday she was suffocated—on the Sunday I observed a bruise on her forehead, over the eye—I saw no mark on her neck—she never showed me any mark—I never saw it—I did not see it after her death.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How was she dressed about the throat? A. She had a gown that came high up in the neck, and she always had a handkerchief on under that, so that you could not see her neck—I did not see the body after death—my mother was with her when she died—I was not—her name was Mary.

WILLIAM HENRY PALMER. I am a bricklayer, living in John-street—I knew the deceased. On the Saturday night before she died, about half-past nine o'clock, I was standing at my own door, and heard a noise from the court where the prisoner lived—I went to the house, and found the prisoner and his wife quarrelling—the wife said to me, "For God's sake, take him away; for I am afraid he will kill me," or something to that effect—I went in on two occasions—the first time I went in by the door, nobody was there then but the prisoner and his wife—I remained about five minutes that time—I said to the prisoner, "What is all this notice about?"—he said, "Oh, it is all right, old fellow!"—I said, "Well, put on your jacket, and come out with me; what is the use of quarrelling?"—he said, "No, I will go up stairs to bed"—I then came out—I went again from a quarter to half-an-hour afterwards, because there was a second disturbance—the door was shut then, and I got in by the window—I then saw the prisoner, the deceased, and the last witness in the room—I was there scarcely a minute that time—the son came in, and directly he came in I came out—the deceased seemed in a dreadfully agitated state, the first time I went in; and so did the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she complain of having received any injury or any violence whatever? A. She did not, she mad no complaint of any kind, no further than saying, "Take him away"—he appeared to have been drink
ing too much, and was in a very excited state.

JOHN KILLEEN (policeman, P 309.) On the Saturday night in question the prisoner's son came to fetch me, and I went to the house about half-past nine o'clock—I saw the deceased there, and no one else—I saw a bruise on her face, I believe over the right eye; she drew my attention to it—that
was all she pointed out to me, and all I observed—she made a complaint to me, but did not charge anybody.

ANN NORTON. I am the wife of Stephen Norton. I knew the deceased—I went there on the Thursday, the day she died—I was present when she died, and assisted in laying her out—I had seen her that same morning, but not lately before that—I found her sitting in the chair—she said she was very ill—I went away at that time—I was sent for a half-past eight o'clock and found her in her daughter's arms vomiting blood—she died in my arms directly afterwards.

WILLIAM OLDS. I am fourteen years old, and lived with the prisoner and the deceased, my father and mother. On the Saturday night before she died I was at home—my father and mother and I were in the house above nine o'clock, nobody else—my mother had had some money left her—I believe it was kept in a drawer of a cheat of drawers that was there—when my father came home he said, "I want some money"—he was not sober my mother said, "No," she would not give it him; and he took hold of the drawers by the bottom and turned them over—I believe the money was in those drawers—I never saw any there—my father went backwards to get the hammer to break the drawers open—my mother took the hammer out of his hand, and threw it over the pigstye—he then began quarrelling and hitting her—they were both quarrelling—I did not see my mother hit him, nor my father hit her—I went out to fetch a policeman—my mother was then in the front room—she was standing up—I did not see her down upon the ground at all—I went for the policeman because my mother sent me—I did not see my father do anything to her—she was sitting down in a chair when I went for the policeman—my father was standing by the fire-side—he was not quiet, he was making a noise and row—I did not see him doing any-thing else—I should have seen it if it had been so—my mother hallooed one two or three times, "Run for a policeman," and I did so—I did not see anybody hold my mother round the body.

COURT. Q. Had your mother had her supper at that time? A. Yes—there was some beer there for mother and father's supper—we had not had our supper—the cloth was on the table—we were going to have some bear and oysters—the oysters were on the table—when my father came down he took the beer and shoved it off the table—my mother did nothing upon that—she was not pleased at it—she said, "That did not hurt me"—he then knocked out the candle—there was only one candle there—then he began his row—I heard him rustling about, and my mother hallooed out two or three times, "Run and fetch the policeman"—she said nothing else.

Q. Recollect yourself; although the prisoner is your father, you must speak the truth; what makes you say he began to make a row when the candle was out; what did you hear? A. Mother said, "Run, he will kill me, he will kill me!"—I did not hear the noise of any blows struck—the table was not turned over—as soon as the row commenced I ran out—it was quite dark—there was no fire—I do not know what the rustling was about—there was no one else there to rustle about, except my father and mother—when I came back again I had a policeman with me—there was no light then—the policeman turned on his lantern—I went to bed two or three hours after that—I had no supper afterwards—there was a light got before I went to bed—my mother lighted a candle—I did not see any mark on her face that sight—I am quite sure about that—I first saw any mark on her face on the Sunday morning—I was not disturbed in the night after this.
WILLIAM HACKETT SHAW (police-inspector P.) I took the prisoner into

custody on the Sunday night after the deceased's death—he was not sober, and I did not tell him the charge till next morning—I then read it over to him, that it was on suspicion of causing the death of his wife, by violently assaulting her on the night of the 21st of Aug.—he said, "Well, I deny that; I don't recollect striking her at all; but I was very much in liqnor at the time"—the boy William was present at the time the charge was taken, and I said to him, in the prisoner's presence, "Why, you are the boy that came to the station for assistance last Saturday night"—he commenced crying—the prisoner said, "Mind what you are after with that boy"—I repeated the question to the boy, and told him to tell me—he began to cry, and said, "How am I to get my living afterwards?"—I do not recollect that he said anything else.

COURT to MR. GOWAR. Q. You know the condition in which this woman's lungs were, in point of disease; from your inspection, suppose a person so afflicted was very much exasperated and excited by anger, would that be likely to produce hemorrhage? A. It would not, I think, to the extent which I observed—I think the excitement from anger might not the sufficient.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 54.—
Confined Three Months.

2237.
JOHN ANNS was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining, by false pre
tences, 5s. 2d., the moneys of the
Eastern Counties Railway Company; he was also charged with obtaining money from two other Railway Companies: to all of which he pleaded.

GUILTY. Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

2238.
JOHN CUSICK and
JAMES CHIDDY were indicted for
feloni
ouely breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Field, at Lambeth, and stealing therein 1 pencil-case, value 18s. 1 locket, 30s.; and 1 shirt-stud, 1s. 6d.; her goods: 12 spoons, 5l.; 1 fork, 1l.; 1 strainer, 15s.; 1 pepper castor-top, 2s.; 1 mustard-pot, 2l.; 1 scarf, 13s.; and 1 half-sovereign; the property of
Ann Wanless: to which

CUSICK pleaded
GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

ELIZABETH FIELD. I am a widow, and reside at No. 50, Henry-street, Kennington-lane. On Sunday evening, the 19th of Sept., about twenty minutes to seven o'clock, I left home to go to chapel—I left no one in the house—I saw that it was all safe—I locked up both in front and behind myself—I pulled the street-door after me—it has a spring-lock—I brought away the key—I locked the gate of the garden in front of my house, and brought away the key—all the windows were left fast—I was called out of chapel, and got back to my house about half-past seven—I found the garden gate unfastened—the street door was shut, as I had left it—I opened it with my key, and went in—I could not have told that anybody had got in—the door must have been opened by a key—there were no marks of violence—it was not a latch-key, but a large street-door key—I first went into my front par
lour, and missed nothing from there—the tea-caddy was laid on the back—parlour table, with the lock hanging to it—there was nothing but the sugar in it—it had been broken open—nothing was taken from it—the drawers in the back parlour had been opened, and the contents were strewed on the floor—I

went into my own chamber, missed a gold pencil-case, a locket, and one shirt-stud—I had a lodger, named Ann Wanless, who had left on the Saturday evening to go into country—I went into her room, and found there had been a visitor there—her writing-desk had the lock broken, the things were strewed on the table, and some articles of plate were gone—I know these articles of plate—(produced)—they belong to Ann Wanless—I had seen them on the premises on the Saturday on which she felt, and they were gone on the Sunday evening—I can swear to all of them—I should say the pro
perty exceeds the value of 5l.—these are all silver.

FLORES EMMENS. I am single, and live next door to Mrs. Field. On Sunday evening, the 19th of Sept., I remember seeing her go out to chapel—I observed her lock the door and gate—about ten minutes or quarter of an hour after she was gone, I saw two men near her house—I watched them—they stood near our railing, loitered about a little while, then crossed the road, came back again, opened the gate, and went into her house—I do not know how they undid the gate, but I saw them undo the door—they applied some thing to the door, opened it, went in, shut the door after them, and I heard the blinds in the house pulled down—I went for a policeman.

CAROLINE RUSH. I am the wife of John Rush, of No. 15, Henry-street, opposite to Mrs. Field's. On this Sunday evening Miss Emmens' sister came across, and told me something; in consequence of which, I looked out towards Mrs. Field's house, and saw the figures of two people moving in the first floor front room—the blinds were drawn down, the candle was on the opposite side of the room they were white holland blinds, and the candle showed their figures—they were removing things constantly to and fro—I could not see the articles they moved—I saw them moving things from the cheffonier in the room—before the policeman came, I saw two persons came out of the house—it was not light enough for me to observe them, but I could see their figures very well—one was a short stout man, and the other tall and thin—I screamed out when I saw them come out—they heard at and attempted to strike my husband, who came up—they ran away—I ran after them—they got out of my sight—I did not see either of them taken—I afterwards saw one of them in the hands of constable Sewry, he resembled the tall man I had seen—I afterwards saw some skeleton keys lying in Mr. Field's garden, and I found just inside the garden the top of a silver cruet.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you undertake to swear whether there were two or three persons in the room? A. Two—I saw them come out—I was standing on the pavement outside my gate, and I could discern two figures—I should say Chiddy was one of those two persons, by this figure—I cannot swear to the face—I will not swear that he was one of the two.

JOHN SEWRY (policeman, L 33.) I was on duty in Kennington-lane on this Sunday evening—in consequence of what I heard, I obtained the assist
ance of another policeman—he went to the back part of Mrs. Field's house, and I went to the front—just before I got to the top of Henry-street I heard a cry of "Stop them, there they go!" and I saw the two prisoners come run
ning up Henry street—Mrs. Rush pointed to the tall one (Chiddy) and de
sired me to stop him—I stopped him—she said he was one of the two men that were in the house—he said he knew nothing about it—I had laid hold of him at the time—he said, "What do you want to stop me for, I am a respectable man?"—I said, "If you are a respectable man you are my pri
soner, and must go to the station"—he asked me what I wanted to take him there for, and resisted very much—I called the assistance of a civilian, who was there, to help me, and took him to the station—before I had him in cus
tody

I saw him throw something away in the shape of a crowbar, or jemmy, I could not exactly see, it was between the lights—he threw it into a garden-gate—after I had lodged him at the station I went back to Mrs. Field's house, and found these five skeleton-keys in her garden—Chiddy must have out at the gate—in the road, I found this top of a wine
strainer, a candle, some matches, and these bits of handkerchief—these silver spoons were picked up by another witness, and this life-preserver was given me by a man picked it up over in a garden, in the direction in which I had seen Chiddy throw something—I did not see it found.

Cross-examined. Q. You said he threw something away like a crow bar? A. I would not swear it was a crowbar—I will swear he threw something—the life-preserver was given me next evening—I should have gone to the house that night, but I could not have got in, as the man was in bed—he is not here—Chiddy said that he was in Henry-street making water, and he heard cries of "Murder," and "Stop thief." and that he ran up—when I stopped him, he said he was innocent.

WILLIAM WRSTON (policeman, L 65.) On the Sunday evening in ques
tion I went toward the back of Mrs. Field's house—I heard a cry that the men had got out—I went round to the front and met Cusick, and took him into custody—I searched him, and found on him this silver mustard-pot, seven desert-spoons, part of a wine-strainer, two salt-spoons, one mustard-spoon, a gold pencil-case, a gold locket, a silver shirt-stud, a knife, and several skeleton-keys—this crowbar was picked up and given to me.

ANN WANLESS. I am single, and lodge at Mrs. Field's. I left home on the Saturday before the robbery, and returned on the Wednesday evening—these articles are all mine, except the locket and pencil-case—I left them all safe in my room when I left on Saturday evening.

JOHN SEWRY
re-examined. I was before the Magistrate when Chiddy made a statement that was taken down, read over to him, and signed by the Magistrate—this is Mr. Elliott's signature—(read"The prisoner Chiddy says, I was standing in Henry-street making water; I heard the cry of 'Stop thief!' and 'Murder!' I ran up the street, and the policeman laid hold of me; I asked him what he stopped me for, and said I was innocent of it")—the wine-strainer was picked up in the road four or five yards from Mrs. Field's—I saw both the prisoners running up the middle of the road together—one was on one side of the way, and the other on the other—I did not see Chiddy near spot where anything was found.

2239.
SARAH BROOKS was indicted
for stealing 4 sovereigns, and 2 half-sovereigns, the monies of
Frederick Dadswell, from his person, having been before convicted of felony.

FREDERICK DADSWELL. I am shopman to Frederick Price, of Bishops
gate-street. On the 30th of Aug., about twelve o'clock at night, I was in High-street, Borough—the prisoner stopped me, and wished me to go to a house in King-street with her, which I would not do—she would not leave me—after refusing her several times, we went into a public-house, and I gave her a pint of beer, with an understanding that she was to leave me—that was five minutes after I first met her—we came out—I told her to go one way, and I would go the other—she would not, but kept hold of my arm, and followed me—she pulled me into another public-house by force, and called for some gin—I told her she ought not to do it—I paid 5d. for it—we came out—I told her to have me—we stood still together ten minutes, opposite the Town-hall—I

did not see a policeman—I should not have given her in charge if I had—I went towards the Borough-market—she attempted to pull me into another-public-house—she suddenly pulled me into a dark court, and closed the door—I felt my money in my pocket then—she began unbuttoning my trowsers, saying as I had treated her she would treat me—I felt for my money, missed it, seized her hands, and said she had robbed me—she struggled to get away—she said I had dropped something—I dragged her out, met a policeman at the court door, and gave her in charge—she told the parcel—I had four sovereigns and two half-sovereigns in a piece of newspaper in my right hand trowser's pocket a quarter of a minute before I missed them.
Prisoner. Q. Did you say as you had treated me I must treat you? A. No.

CHARLES M'CARTHY (policeman, M 252.) On the 30th of Aug. I was on duty in the Borough-market—Dadswell gave the prisoner into my charge—she said she heard something drop in the court—he charged her with stealing few sovereigns and two half-sovereigns—she denied it—I took her to the station.

MARY ANN RANDALL. I search females at the Southwark Police-station—the prisoner was brought to the station—she said she had got no money—I searched her, and found four sovereigns and two half-sovereigns, wrapped up in a piece of paper—she took it from me once, and wished me to keep it, and not say anything about it.
Prisoner. I did not wish you to keep it; I wished to know what it contained.

FREDERICK DADSWELL
re-examined. There is no mark on this paper—it was such a piece of newspaper as this—to the best of my belief it is the same.
Prisoner's Defence. If I had known it belonged to the gentleman, I would given it him.
GEORGE WILD (policeman, M 94.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted Aug., 1845. and confined one year)—I was present at the trial—she is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2240.
HENRY KITCHENER was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of scales, value 2s.; 1 frame and glass, 1s. 6d.; 1 cannister, 6d.; 1 bottle, 6d.; 1 clock, 5s.; 1 carpet, 2s.; and other articles, value 20l.; the goods of
Robert Lewis King.

MARY KING. I am the wife of Robert Lewis King, of Norfolk-street, Southwark Bridge-road. The prisoner is my son, but not my husband's son—my husband and I were tried for felony—it was for keeping goods sent to us to mangle—we were acquitted—we had the goods in the house, but we did not know who they belonged to—before we were acquitted the prisoner came for the key of the house, to take care of the things—when we were acquitted, we went back to the house, found it quite empty, and the key given up to the land-lord—we lost the whole of our household furniture—18l. or 19l. would not replace them—I have seen the things produced—I am confident this gown and shawl are mine—the other things are my husband's, and were in the house when we were taken to prison.

Prisoner. Q. On the 23rd of July did not you give me the key to pledge the things and pay the back rent? A. No. you sent a letter to me at Horse-monger-lane, and said if I would allow you to have the key, you would live in my cottage, and take care of it, and pay the rent till I came home.

COURT. Q. How was he to pay the rent? A. Nothing was said about that—if he had pledged things to pay the rent I should have thought nothing about it—he had no authority to pledge things—he come to me on the following Thursday week, and told me he had moved part of the things from the cottage—I asked him what he had moved them for—he said he did not think, it I was acquitted, I should like to come to the same neighbour
hood to live.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not ask me, at the police-court, what I had made away with, to pay the back rent, and did not I say, "Mr. King's cost?" A. I know nothing about pledging anything to pay back rent—you said you had moved the things into Lant-street—that was a wrong address.

ROBERT LEWIS KING. I am the husband of the last witness. When we were acquitted we went back to our house, and missed everything we had left there—I went to Lant-street, in search of the prisoner—he was not there—I found him in Billingagate, and gave him in charge—he said at the station he had pawned my clothes, and sold his mother's in Petticoat-lane—he did not say he had any authority to do it—he had none from me.

ALEXANDER HAUGHEY (policeman, P 188.) I took the prisoner, and told him Mr. King charged him with taking all he had got from his cottage, and asked him where the things were—he told me he had sold them in Petticoat-lane—I asked if he had any idea who to—he said, "No"—I asked him about Mr. King's clothes—he said they were pawned at William's, in the Borough—at the police-court he said he had sold the things to a broker, (he would not tell where,)and part of them at the house where he lived—the Magistrate ordered me to go with him the following day to his lodgings, No. 5, Norfolk-street—we there found a lot of property—he took me to Long-lane, Bermond
sey—we there found a great deal there—we have got the greatest part of it back—I produce some duplicates which I found at the prisoner's lodging.

JAMES EDWARD MORGAN. I am a furniture-broker, at 168, Bermondsey-street. About the 5th of Aug. the prisoner came to me, and said a person named Reynolds had sent him, who had seen some furniture which he had to sell, but they were not good enough for him, and asked if I would buy it—I went to No. 5, Norfolk-street, and bought a bedstead, a bed, five chairs, and four boxes, which have since been owned by Mr. King.

ROBERT LEWIS KINGS
re-examined. I have been to Mr. Morgan's and seen the articles—they are all my property.

Prisoner. They are not; they were my mother's, and you are not mar
ried to her, though you live as man and wife. Witness. They are the pro
perty of the house, and were under my care.
SAMUEL ALLMAN. I am a shoemaker. I bought some crockery ware, chins, and glass, to the amount of 7s. 11d., at No. 5, Norfolk-street—I occupy the bottom of the house.

MARY KING
re-examined. I have seen the things bought by Allman—they are my property.

DAVID GRIMMETT. I am in the employ of Edward Burles, King's-road, Walworth. I produce two pillows and two waistcoats, pledged by a woman, at the latter end of July—I gave a duplicate for them, it is among these produced—Mrs. King has seen them.

MRS. REYNOLDS. I keep a furniture-broker's shop. The prisoner came to me, and said he had some furniture to sell, and asked if I would buy it—I said, "Yes," if it suited me—he said he was not quite ready then, but next morning he would be prepared for me—he came next morning, and said, "I have got the things to dispose of; I am going into the country, and must sell
them to-day"—I went him to Norfolk-street, and saw some things, but did not buy them—I recommended him to go to Mr. Morgan.
Prisoner's Defence. She ordered me to pawn something to pay the back rent, which was done the next day, the 22nd of July; they have been to the landlord; and they know that the rent is paid.

ROBERT LEWIS KING
re-examined. He paid 6s. rent, which he pawned a coat for—the rent was 3s. a week—the goods are worth 18l. or 19l.—he never gave me any money for the goods he sold.

MARY KING
re-examined. He never gave me any money—he had as commission from us to sell.

GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

2241.
WILLIAM JOLLY and
PHŒBE JOLLY , were indicted for
steal
ing, at Christchurch, 12 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 2 half-crowns, 5 shillings, and 1 groat; the moneis of
Robert Corlett, in the dwelling-house of
James Richard Gale.

ROBERT CORLETT. I am a clerk in the General Post-office, and live in Hatfield-street. Mr. Gale is the landlord—the prisoner lived on the same floor with me. On Sunday afternoon, the 5th of Sept., about half-past five o'clock, I went into my room and found my trunk open—it had been locked before I went out—I missed 12l. 10s. in gold, two half-crowns, 3s., and a four penny piece—I had put some of it in on the Saturday afternoon before—one of the shillings had a hole through it—I had locked up my box, and taken my key with me—I went with two policemen to the prisoner's room and saw then—they gave leave to have their boxes searched—I saw two half-sovereign found, and two half-crowns and five shillings, the same amount of coin as my silver, except the fourpenny piece—one of the shillings had a hole in it, similar to the one I missed—the gold is gone.

William Jolly. Q. Did you describe that shilling to the policeman? Witness. No; I described the coin, but forgot the shilling with the hole in it—there is no other coin which I can identify—the gold was nearly new—I know the half-sovereign was dated 1847, the one found is of the same date—the fourpenny piece was one of King William's—the other people's boxes were not searched.

SARAH GALE. I am wife of James Gale, of Hatfield-street—my husband rents the house, lives in it himself, and lets out apartments—I believe it is is the parish of Christchurch—on Wednesday, the 18th, the prisoners came to lodge there—they passed as man and wife, and said they had just come from Man
chester—Corlett lodged there on the Friday before this happened—he sent me for change for a sovereign—I gave it him, and noticed a shilling with a hole in it—on Sunday, the 5th of Sept., about five o'clock in the afternoon, William Jolly came down stairs, he seemed rather confused, and asked me for the bellows—I said I was using them—he after wards came down, I gave them to him, and he went out—he was out about fan hour and a half—I was not out of the house during that time—I opened the door to him—I had not opened the door to any one while he was out, except Mr. Corlett—no stranger came in during that time—there was no other person on that floor but Corlett, the prisoners, and myself—I am quite sure this shilling (produced) is the one I got.
William Jolly's Defence. The money found on us was our own; I heard several persons enter Corlett's room during the day.

SARAH GALE
re-examined. A lady and gentleman came to my house on Saturday night, and took the lower room, but they have not seen the top room—they are very respectable people, and are still there—I swear they
had no opportunity of going up stairs to that floor—I was with then all the time.

JURY. Q. What part of the house do you do you live in? A. The kitchen, which is up stairs—the lady and gentleman live in the room above—they could not go to the room above without my knowing it, because they did not know the way of the house, or who I had got in it—they were hardly out of the room during the day I went for the change.

ROBERT CORLETT
re-examined. I came home on the Saturday evening, be
tween eight and nine—I remained down stairs with Mr. and Mrs. Gale, not in the room where I kept my money—I had left that room soon after four—I locked it, had the key with me, and the key of my box—I did not go up to the room till I went to bed—the box was not opened then—the money could not have been taken till Sunday—I slept there that night, and left the trunk safe at a quarter-past ten on Sunday morning—I tried it.

JURY. Q. Had you the key of the room with you on Sunday morning? A. No, I left it in the door for Mrs. Gale to make up the room—the lid of the trunk was not broken, it was unlocked—it did not seem to have been forced—I tried the key of my room to a box in the prisoners' room, in the prisoner's presence, and it fitted it; but I have not seen the key of the pri
soners' box.
WILLIAM GREY (policeman.) I took the prisoners, and found the money in their box—the house is in the parish of Christchurch.

JURY to SARAM GALE. Q. Was the hole in the shilling a drilled hole, or a punched hole? A. It was a little raised on one side—it was at the top of the head—I had received a fortnight's rent from them—14s. altogether, 4s. of which was for attendance during her confinement—it was all in shillings—I did not see them with any gold.

WILLIAM JOLLY—
GUILTY.

PHŒBE JOLLY—
NOT GUILTY.

2242.
WILLIAM JOLLY and
PHŒBE JOLLY were again indicted for
stealing 1 crown, 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence; the monies of
Mary Ann Carnes.

MARY ANN CARNES. I am a widow, and live at 9, Princes-street, Union-street. On the 11th of July the prisoner Phoebe came to me, told me she was a cap-maker, and wanted part of a bed—I took her to sleep with me—I took her for a single woman—on the Tuesday before she left on the Wed
nesday, the prisoner William came—they had an interview—they did not say what relationship there was between them, they both break fasted with me that morning—I went out between twelve and one o'clock, leaving them in my room, and nobody in the house but a little girl twelve years old—I was away three quarters of an hour or an hour, came back, and found the prisoners had just dined—they left between seven and eight o'clock, leaving no one in the house but me—he said to her, "Now, my dear, shall I take your box;" he went away taking her box—two hours afterwards I went to my drawers, I found them locked as I had left them, and missed my money which had been in a little brown bag—nobody else had been in the house—I did not see the prisoners again till they were in custody—I had given her warning—I never saw bag or money again—there was nearly 3l. in it.

William Jolly. Q. Did not a young man lodge in the house? A. Not that night—there was only an old man lodged in the house, he house, he was out all day—I had seen my money in the drawers the night before—they had not been opened since: I had the key in my pocket.

William Jolly's Defence. I came up from the country, and joined my wife, who was living at this house, intending to get furnished lodgings next day; we got lodgings at Mrs. Gale's, in Hatfield-street, not ten minutes walk from the prosecutrix's, who we met frequently in the streets, and she did not say a word about this affair till we were examined the third time at the Police-court on the other charge.

MARY ANN CARNES
re-examined. I never saw them after they left, till they were in custody, they might have seen me—I found out that they were in custody by Mrs. Gale coming to know where they lived before—I did not know where they went to.
William Jolly. I said we are going not far from you, into Hatfield-street. Witness. Nothing of the kind passed—if I had met you I should have given you in charge

WILLIAM JOLLY—
GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

PHŒBE JOLLY—
NOT GUILTY.

2243.
JOHN PARKER was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 5s. 6d.; the goods of Thomas Robert Dutton: and having been before con
victed of felony.

FREDRICK HENSTOCK I am shopman to Thomas Robert Dutton, a boot-maker. On Friday evening, the 20th of Sept., I was at the end of the counter, near the window—I could not be seen from the door—I saw the prisoner take a pair of boots from the stand, put them under his coat, and walk out of the shop—I went out, found him standing two shops off, took hold of him, and taxed him with having the boots—he dropped them at my feet, and said, "He gave them me"—he did not point to anybody—I am sure he is the person—he was never out of my sight—these boots are Thomas Robert Dutton's.

JOSEPH RACKSTRAW (policeman.) I was duty, and saw the prisoner struggling with Henstock—I took him and the boots—these are them (pro
duced)—going to the station, the prisoner said he did not steal them, some one gave them to him.
JOHN UNDERWOOD (policeman.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted, May, 1843,and confined three months)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY.**† Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2244.
MATILDA BATES was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; and 1 bag, 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Henry Dove: and 1 curtain, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
John Spencer, her master: to which she pleaded

2245.
MATILDA BATES
was anain indicted for stealing 2 brushes, value 2s. 6d.; 2 yards of satin, 3s.; 1 box of tooth-powder, 1s.; and 1 bottle of tartaric-acid, 1s.; the goods of
John Spencer, her master.

THOMISINA SPENCER. I am the wife of john Spencer, of Larkhall-rise, Clapham. The prisoner was in my service—I gave her notice to leave on the 22nd of Sept.—I had given her a character for another place that morning—I had no idea that she was dishonest, except in petty things—the same afternoon I went into her bedroom with a friends, who took up her comb-bag—the prisoner was not there, she was down stairs—we found in it two tooth-brushes, and a nail-brush with "15d." marked on it—the private mark was erased—I could see that it had been there at the time but the mark and price is rubbed off now—I am able to swear they are my husband's—they were never sold—I called the prisoner

up, and said, "Matilda, you have been taking things that do not belong to you, out of the surgery"—she said, "No, I have not"—she afterwards said, "Pray, ma'am, forgive me"—I opened her box, and found some trimming, and some stuff cut into pocket-handkerchiefs, a baby's frock cut into hand
kerchiefs—a box which had been taken out of a drawer, and then filled with tooth-powder—it was our box and tooth-powder; also a box of pastiles; also a puff-box and powder, which was taken from a glass-case in my dress
ing-room—I also found a handkerchief of mine under her pillow—she said she had taken them, and prayed of me not to expose her, as I had given her the character—I desired her to undress herself, she refused—I said I must call in a policeman—she said, "Call one in"—she presently asked me if she gave me all she had, if I would call one in—I said I would make on promise—she pulled a bead-purse from under her dress—I also found a packet of violet powder which had been taken out of the surgery—she had lived with me a fortnight—I had a character for honesty with her.
JOHN DEMPSEY (policeman) I took the prisoner—she said she did not know what possessed her to do such a thing—I received the property from Mrs. Spencer.

2246.
GEORGE STREAK was indicted
for stealing 1 ass, price 1l. 5s.; the property of
William Edwards.

WILLIAM EDWARDS. I live in Little Manor-street, Clapham. On Friday, the 5th of Aug., I had a donkey turned out on Clapham-common—I saw it safe at nine o'clock in the morning, and missed it about half-past nine—I saw it again about four the same afternoon, in Smithfield—a man named Timson had it there for sale.

EDWARD LAWRENCE. I live at Walworth. On the 6th of Aug., about twelve o'clock in the day, I was in Blackfriars-road—I saw a donkey—a little boy was riding it, and the prisoner was walking by the side of it—the prisoner asked me to buy the donkey—he asked 12s. for it—I said I had only 8s.—they went on about forty yards, and then the little boy came run
ing back, and said I should have it—I bought it for 8s.—I am sure it was the prisoner who offered me the donkey for sale—I took it to my own home, and put it in harness to see if it would be of any use to me, and it would not, it laid down—I sent Timson to sell it for half a guinea—I afterwards heard something, and the prisoner was given in charge.

WALTER CHARLES DODD. I live at No. 2, Union-street, Walworth. I was with Lawrence when he bought the donkey—I saw the prisoner—he had a boy with him—I did not hear the dealing, but I saw the money paid by Lawrence to the prisoner.

WILLIAM GIBBS (policeman, V 77.) I apprehended the prisoner—I told him he was charge with stealing a donkey—he told me he did not take the donkey off the common; but if he had been present when the other boy was tried, he would have given the young b—r more than he had got.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the boy on Kennington-common; he asked me to go with him; I went with him to Blackfriars-road, and he sold it there; he said, "It is one of Mr. Edwards's donkeys, but don't say anything about it;" he gave me half the money, and had half himself.

2247.
JAMES LAWSON,
BENJAMIN LAWSON,
WILLIAM JOHN
SON , and
JOHN MURPHY , were indicted for
stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 2 shillings, and 3 sixpences the property of John Rathbone Taylor, from the person of
Caroline Taylor; and that Murphy had been before convicted of felony: to which

JAMES LAWSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

BENJAMIN LAWSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Three Months.

WILLIAM JOHNSON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

CAROLINE TAYLOR. I am the wife of John Rathbone Taylor—I was walking down Blackfriars-road on the 16th of Aug.—I had a purse with me containing shillings and sixpences—one of the sixpences was battered—I went on to the London-road—I was spoken to by Pound—I felt in my pocket, and my purse was gone—this now produced is it—this sixpence is similar to the one I had—the prisoners were not in sight when I was spoken to—I had seen James Lawson several times before in the London-road.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK Q. You do not swear to this six
pence? A. No. nor to Murphy.

WILLIAM POUND. I am a labourer, and live in Duke-street. On the 16th of Aug. I was in the Blackfriars-road, and saw Mrs. Taylor—the two Law
sons were there—James Lawson had a butcher's frock on—I saw Benja
min Lawson attempt to Mrs. Taylor's pocket close by Charlotte-street—she was walking away from Blackfriars-bridge towards the Obelisk—I saw Johnson and Murphy about a quarter of an hour afterwards in conversation together, near the Duke of Clarence, at the corner of the London-road-Mrs. Taylor came up, followed by the two Lawsons—Johnson and Murphy joined the two Lawsons, and they had a conversation together close by Mr. Alder's, the cook's shop—they then went on, and I saw Benjamin Law
son take the purse from Mrs. Taylor's pocket, and they all ran away—Mrs. Taylor had made a stop, and the purse was then taken—the prisoner ran down Gaywood-street—I went another way, round West-square—I found them in St. George's-road—I afterwards took the two Lawsons.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure it was Murphy you saw? A. Yes, I have known him for the last twelve or fourteen years—he was close to Benja
min Lawson when he took the purse, and he held his coat up—he was taken the same evening—I collared the two Lawsons—Murphy and Johnson ran back from the other two—I had just left my work, and was coming along Blackfriars-road—I deliver bills for the different theatres, the Surrey and Astley's, and the Victoria—I had left off at four o'clock, and was coming home—I am not supposed to deliver bills every day—I only do so once a week—sometimes I get a job otherways—I was a constable eight years—when I see a person robbed, I am the first to go to take the thief—I do not do a bit of police-work unless 1 see a person robbed—I followed Mrs. Taylor all the way to the London-road, because I was quite satisfied they were going to rob her—I left the police, as I told you once before, because I got a drop too much—I always feel proud of coming as a witness if I see a person robbed-perhaps I may have been a witness fifty times at the Old Bailey and Surrey Sessions, and several other places, out of town and in town—I am not aware what they call me—perhaps the thieves may call me a policeman's cad—I do not know it—I am always the first to give information—perhaps they would take me back into the police if I were to ask them.

DAVID COTTON. I saw all the prisoners that night, between six and half-past six o'clock, by the corner of the Duke of Clarence, in the Circus, leading up from the London-road—I saw Pound take the two Lawsons into custody, and I saw this purse drop from Johnson.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you refer to Murphy as being there? A. Yes—I had not known him before—I am sure it was him—I never saw him till he was taken into custody—that was after the lady had been robbed—Pound took the two Lawsons, and called to Stroud, and said, "Take these other two men"—I saw nothing of the lady—I saw Johnson drop this purse—I did not hear any cry of "Police."

JOHN BAKER (policeman, L 128.) Pound pointed out Murphy, and I took him into custody—he was not with the other three prisoners when I took him—he was with them when he came out of the St. George's tavern—he had been pointed out to me when he was in the tavern—they came out, and walked about 100 yards, and then Murphy left the other three, and went back, and I took him—I found on him 1s., a knife, and two penny-pieces—on Johnson I found 4s., two sixpences, 9d. in halfpence, and a comb—among the sixpences was this battered one.
Cross-examined. Q. All you know is, that Pound pointed out Murphy and the others being all together? A. Yes, they were close together when they came out of the tavern.

JESSE CANNON (policeman, L 69.) I produce a certificate of Murphy's former conviction at this court—(read—Convicted the 7th of April, 1845,and confined two years)—I was present at the trial—he is the man.

MURPHY—
GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2248.
CHARLES GIBSON ROGERS was indicted
for embezzling 19s. 8 1/2d.; the moneys of
George Marshall, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Six Months.

2249.
JOHN WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing 120lbs. weight of lead, value 1l.; the goods of the
South Eastern Railway Company.

WILLIAM SHAW. I am in the employ of the South Eastern Railway Company. I attend to the goods department at the Bricklayer's Arms station, on the night duty—the goods at this time of year chiefly come up at night—we have two trains come in, one at twelve o'clock, and the Dover train at half-past three o'clock in the morning—they bring market goods; fruit, fish, and meat—the prisoner was in the employ of Mrs. Stansbury, who carries goods from the station in her own carts—they come about two o'clock every morning, and take fruit, and meat—the cart the prisoner was attached to was driven by Neale, the prisoner was guard to it—on the morning of the 2nd of Sept., I particularly noticed two pieces of lead, which had been brought up from Ashford, and were about to be put in the stores—they were the property of the Company—I saw it safe about two o'clock that morning—I afterwards saw the same lead at Aldermanbury—the prisoner and Neale had been at the station before two o'clock that morning—their employ
ment would give them opportunity to take that lead, if they were disposed to do it—they had their fruit in what we term the dock—after I had been told of the discovery of the lead I went after the prisoner—I found him at the east end of the town—I got him to return with me to Aldermanbury—the

lead was produced, and I asked him how he came in possession of it—he said he found it in the yard of the George, Aldermanbury—there was a bag there, which he said belonged to Neale—I have never seen Neale since I found the lead.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. How far is Mrs. Stansburry's yard from the railway station. A. I should say two miles and a half, or it may be three miles—I observed the two pieces of lead at two o'clock in the morning, on the 2nd of Sept.—there was gas burning in the warehouse—I never took it in my hand—I had looked down upon it and noticed it—there were only these two pieces on the premises—there were a number of persons coming backwards and forwards to this particular spot, perhaps fifteen or sixteen—there are only nine porters there at nigh—I do not know how many there are by day—I know nothing about the day duty—I saw this lead safe at two o'clock, and the prisoner was found with it about eleven o'clock in the morning—I did not miss it from the premises till ten o'clock in the morning—we have had great reason to complain of persons pilfering on the premises—I did not offer the prisoner five shillings if he would tell me the person who had taken the lead.

MR. BODKIN. Q. How long had the lead been there after its arrival? A. It came on the 31st of Aug.—my attention was called to it before the morning of the 2nd of Sept., and I had spoken to the men about it—I saw it in the same place on the 2nd of Sept., at two o'clock in the morning, I missed it at ten o'clock, and did not see it again till after the prisoner had been taken, about seven o'clock in the evening—I am quite confident it is the same lead I saw at the station—the prisoner has been in the habit of coming there for about twelve months—during that time we have lost things—this is the lead—it is worth about 20s.

MR. WILDE. Q. Was Mr. Knowles present when the wagon was loaded? A. He night have been in the office, or on the station—he said in the prisoner's presence that he was quite sure he did not take the lead.

JAMES HILDER. I am managing clerk to Mrs. Stansbury, the carrier, at the George-yard, Aldermanbury. The prisoner was in her employ—he and a man named Neale went with a cart to the Bricklayer's Arms—I can
not say whether the prisoner went with Neale on the morning of the 2nd of Sept.—I was going out of Mrs. Stansbury's yard that morning, and met the prisoner in the street, within two yards of the yard—it was from half-past eleven to twelve o'clock—he had a bag on his back, which appeared to con
tain something heavy—I said, "Well, John, what have you got there?"—he said, "A parcel a person gave me at the station, to deliver just down here"—I said, "Who gave you the parcel?"—he hesitated, and said, "That is of no consequence"—I said, "What is it you have got?"—I put my hand to the bottom of the bag, and felt it was very weighty—I told him to come to the gateway, and show me what he had got—he came and opened the bag, and I saw two pieces of lead in it—I said, "Here is something very mysterious here, it has the appearance of rogueishness, take it to the office up the yard"—he took it to the office, and I had it weighed—one piece weighed 84lbs., the other 36lbs.—he gave no further account of how he became possessed of it—I said I must make further inquiry into it, and the lead was detained at the office—I did not see the prisoner again from that time till seven o'clock in the evening, when Mr. Shaw brought him—the lead was then produced—the prisoner said nothing particular about it that I took notice of—he had said in the morning, when I asked him a second time, that he found it in Neal's van; and another account that he gave in the evening was, that be
picked it up in the yard, and he even went and showed us a spot in the corner of the yard of the tavern where he said he had picked it up.

Cross-examined. Q. You have stated that he always behaved like an honest man, and that a great deal of valuable property has gone through his hands? A. I have—Neale absconded, and I have never seen him since.

GUILTY. Aged 34.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Six Months

2250.
JANE GRIFFITHS was indicted
for stealing 2 aprons, value 2s., and 1 shirt, 3s.; the goods of
Stephen Betts, the younger; and 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d., and 1 curtain, 1s.; the goods of
Stephen Betts, the elder, her master.

MARY BETTS. I am the wife of Stephen Betts, a butcher, at Putney. The prisoner was in my service about three months—on the 31st of Aug., in consequence of some circumstances, I required to search her box—the police
man was sent for; and on her consenting, I went up to her box in her bed-room, and she unlocked it—I found in it two aprons belonging to my son Stephen, and a sheet cut to pieces—I have put it together to see if it would make a sheet—I can swear to it by a B which I put on it myself, and a little dot—I found a long muslin curtain, which was an apron of my daughter's, and I joined it together myself, and made a curtain—it is my own work—I found a night-shirt of my son's in the kitchen table-drawer, which I can swear to by a B that was on it—the letters have been picked out, but I can see that there has been the cotton there—I asked the prisoner how she came by the aprons—she said she had made half-a-dozen aprons for a young man, and he had given her these two—she said the curtain was her own—I said I could swear to it—she said it was hers, and she had more like it—I told her to show me one like it, and she showed me one which was clear muslin—the sheet, she said, she bought of a housemaid at Streatham, where she lived servant—I had never given her these things—she had no right or authority to have them in her box.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is there on the aprons that enables you to know they belong to you? A. I had a dozen of them, and I am two short out of the dozen—I missed them after I had searched her box—these are exactly like the others, and the person who made them is here—this shirt is torn—it is not an old one—here is a darn that I know it by, down the seam, and here is a B on it.
ANN FINN. I live at Roehampton. I made a dozen aprons for Mr. Betts, jun.—I am certain these are two of them—I know my own needle-work.

CHARLES CANHAM (policeman. V 58.) I was called in to be present at the searching of the prisoner's box, and these articles were found—she said she had made half-a dozen aprons for a young man named Jones, in Cookapur-street, and he gave her these two—I went to the place she described, but could not find the person—I communicated to her the result of my inquiry, and she made no answer—she said she bought the sheet of a fellow-servant at Streatham—I went there to make inquiries.
(William Roberts, a linen-draper, in Paul-street, Finsbury, the prisoner's uncle, gave her a good character, and engaged to send for her brother to take her to her friends in the country.)

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—

div1.p:
2251.
JAMES ANDREWS
was indicated for embezzling 8s.; the moneys of
John Jones, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months .

2252.
ELIZA EATON and
THOMAS FOSTER were indicted for
felo
niously receiving 22 yards of cloth, value 18l.; the goods of
William Strange, well knowing them to have been stolen.

WILLIAM STRANGE. I am a tailor, and live at Tunbridge Wells. On the night of the 19th of Aug. I locked up my house and went out, leaving no one at home—I had at that time a quantity of cloth there—I returned the next morning between one and two o'clock, found my house broken open, and missed about 200 yards of cloth, worth between 60l. and 70l.—on the 21st Goddard, the constable came to me, and in consequence of what he said I went to the railway-station—a basket was there opened, and I saw my cloth there—it was repacked, and I saw it again in London—this now produced in it—I have some list here, to compare with this cloth—I am perfectly satisfied it is mine.

THOMAS GODDARD. I am a constable of Tunbridge—on the 21st of Aug. I went to the Railway-station, and found there this hamper—I opened it, and found it contained this cloth—I went to Mr. Strange, who came and identified the cloth—the hamper had been packed up by a basket-maker, and I sent for the same man to repack it—it had this direction on it, "G. Chitty, 2, Arnold's Paragon, Francis-street, Newington Butts, London"—after the hamper per was delivered there, I went into the house—I saw Morton and Eaton talking—the hamper was taken into the parlour, and afterwards taken to the station-house in Lock's-fields.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. It was not opened till it was at the station? A. No.

ISAAC HUBBARD. I am porter to Chaplin and Horne—I took this basket to the house where it is directed—Eaton opened the door—I said I had a hamper, addressed to Mr. Chitty, 2, Arnold's Paragon, Francis-street, New
ington Butts—I asked whether such a person lived there—she said, "Yes bring it in, it is all right"—I set it in the passage, and demanded 3s. 1d., which was paid me—I said I wanted my book signed, and Eaton took it into the room and brought it out signed "J. Chitty"—the direction on the hamper was G. Chitty.

WILLIAM MORTON. (police-serjeant, P 7.) I went with Hubbard on the 23rd of Aug., to deliver the hamper—I saw it delivered, and heard him ask what he has stated—he asked to have his book signed, and Eaton took it into the front parlour—I looked through the window and saw Foster lying in bed—I saw him write in the book, and when it was brought out again, I saw the signature in it, J. Chitty—I then went in, and saw the two prisoner talking in the front parlour—I asked Eaton where the hamper was that had just come—she made no reply—I asked her to come with me, and I went into the back parlour—I there saw the hamper—I asked her what was in it—she said she did not know—I said, "It contains cloth stolen from Tun
bridge Wells, and I shall take you for receiving it knowing it to be stolen—she said she knew nothing about it—I asked where Mr. Chitty resided—she said she did not know, that he had left there six months, and asked her

to take in any parcels that came—I asked if she was landlady of the house—she said "Yes, but she let it all off but that parlour"—I asked her where Chitty lived—she said she did not know—that he traveled the country, and only called there when he came to London—I went into the front parlour, and found in the drawers three letters, addressed to Mr. Chitty—Foster said the drawers did not belong to him nor the letters.
Foster. Q. Who had the key of the drawers? A. Eaton had.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Chitty? A. I do not know that I should—I do not know that I have seen him—I believe a man named Chitty is known to the police—that is not Foster.

JAMES DABSON. I am a constable of Tunbridge Wells—I came to London and saw the hamper delivered—I went immediately afterwards into the room where Foster was in bed—I called to him four or five times—he appeared fast asleep and would not hear anything I said—the book had been signed not half a minute before—I told him to get up, I must take him about the cloth—he said "Cloth, I know nothing about it"—he said his name was not Chitty, it was Foster—I said "Why did you sign the book John Chitty if your name is Foster"—he said Mrs. Eaton the landlady asked him to do it, and he had done it.
Foster. Q. Was it about half a minute after the book was signed that you came in? A. Yes—instantly.
Foster to WILLIAM MORTON. Q. When did you come in? A. Just. afterwards.
Foster. Dabson says I was asleep, and you said I was talking.

Foster's Defence. Respecting those letters that were found in a drawer, locked up, I had been stopping in the house nearly three weeks previously, and Eston had frequently asked me to read and write letters for her; she could not write; she came into the room that morning when this was de
livered, and asked me to sign the book, which I did as a kindness; as to knowing anything at all of the robbery, I do not; the policeman admitted that there is a man named Chitty, who is known; and they know very well my name is Foster; had my name been Chitty, this person would have come and said, "Here is a parcel for you, there is 3s. 1d. to pay;" but she paid that and took it into her own apartment; it had nothing to do with me; she merely came and asked me to sign the book so and so, for her; I know nothing of the affair; I had a great number of persons to come up, who know Chitty, and that my name is Foster.

EATON—
GUILTY. Aged 33.

FOSTER—
GUILTY. Aged 30.
(There was another indictment against Eaton)

2253.
ANN BOWLEY was indicted for
stealing 6 spoons, value 2l.; the property of
William Kinnaird Jenkins, her master; and
SARAH ASHBERRY
for feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to be stolen.
WILLIAM KINNAIRD JENKINS. I live in Victoria Villas, Avilla-road, Regent's Park. Bowley was in my service—about the 27th April, I lost six spoons—these two spoons are mine—they have my mark on them.

HENRY COOK. I am a pawnbroker. I produce these two spoons—Bow
ley offered them to me on the 27th of April—she asked 22s. for them—seeing they were two different crests I asked whose they were—she said they belonged to her sister—I told her to fetch her sister, and in the mean time I sent a young man to watch her, to see where she went to—she walked

about the road for some time, came back, and said her sister wanted them back again, and she would not pawn them at all—the young man I had sent came in, and said she had not been anywhere, only walking about—she seemed confused, and then said she would fetch her sister—she went out, and not coming for an hour I went with the officer to the address she gave me, No. 3, Smith's-place—I saw her sitting at tea with her sister, the prisoner Ashberry—I gave her in charge—Ashberry said, "Good God, you have done for yourself now; come in, the neighbours will hear of it now."

JAMES CUDDY (policeman, L 20.) On the 27th of Aug., I was called by Mr. Cook, and went with him to No. 3, Smith's-place, Gibraltar-row—we found Bowley sitting there—Mr. Cook pointed her out as the person who had offered the spoons—I asked her if she wanted to say anything about the two spoons that she had offered—she said, "Let me have them, I will take them home to my master"—I said, "Where does he live?"—she said, "No.9, Avilla-road, Regent's-part, and his name Jenkins"—I took her to the station—I came back to the house, and asked Ashberry if her sister had left any duplicates there—she said, "No"—I saw her give something to Mr. Cook—I asked what it was, and he gave me a duplicate for two spoons—I said to Ashberry, "Have you any more?"—she handed me a duplicate for two spoons, pawned on the 1st July—she then said, "I have given all I have got, you may search if you please"—I said, "I will not take you, as you have a family; come before the Magistrate to-morrow morning"—I went to Mr. Jenkin's, and found three more duplicates for spoons pawned at Mr. Attenborough's—I went the next day to Ashberry's, and asked why she was not in attendance before the Magistrate—she said, "I went after my girl that pawned the two tea-spoons.
Bowley's Defence. My sister did not know that they were my master's property.

BOWLEY—
GUILTY. Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. —
Confined One Year

ASHBERRY—
NOT GUILTY.

2254.
ANN BOWLEY was again indicted for
stealing 2 spoons, value 8s.; the goods of
William Kinnaird Jenkins, her master;
SARAH ASH
BERRY
for feloniously receiving the same.
WILLIAM KINNAIRD JENKINS. These two spoons are mine—I lost them before the 1st of June.
WILLIAM COOK. I received these two spoons in pledge—I was in the shop at the time they were taken in of Ashberry's daughter.

2255.
ANN BOWLEY was again indicted for
stealing 1 spoon, value 12s.; the goods of
William Kinnaird Jenkins, her master;
SARAH ASH
BERRY
for feloniously receiving the same.
WILLIAM LOWE. I am a pawnbroker. I produce this spoon—this is the duplicate of it—it was written by the lad—I cannot say who took it is.

JAMES CUDDY (policeman, L 20.) The prisoner Ashberry gave me the du
plicate of this spoon on the 27th of Aug.—I asked her if she had pawned it—she said, "Yes, I did, I would not have done so, but my sister told me she meant to take it out when she got her wages."
WILLIAM KINNAIRD JINKINS. This is my spoon.
Ashberry's Defence. I was not aware that they were her master's property.

BOWLEY—
NOT GUILTY.

ASHBERRY—
GUILTY. Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

2256.
JANE EVANS was indicted
for stealing 1 bottle, value 3d.; 1 half-pint of wine, 2s. 6d.; 1 shawl, 3s.; and 1 book, 6s.; the goods of
Thomas Seel, her master.

THOMAS SEEL. I live at Camberwell. The prisoner was in my service. On the 28th of Aug., about six o'clock in the morning, I found that she had left the house, leaving the back door and the front area open—I missed a pair of boots, a bottle of wine, and a shawl—the boots and shawl were found on the prisoner—they are my wife's.

Prisoner. The shawl my mistress gave me—she shook me very much on Saturday—I took the boots for a fortnight's wages, but not with the intention of thieving. Witness. I never heard of any shaking—the prisoner said she had given the bottle of wine away.
JOHN HALL (policeman, M 194.) I took the prisoner—she admitted before the Magistrate that she gave the wine away, that the shawl was given her, and she took the boots.

GUILTY
of stealing the boots. Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

2257.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 4s.; the goods of
Charles Dean; having been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES DEAN. I keep a shop in Saville-row, Walworth-road. On the 31st of Aug., about two o'clock in the afternoon, I received information, and ran out—I missed a coat, which had been outside my shop—I informed the policemen—the coat has not been found.

CHARLES COUSINS. I am a journeyman butcher, and live in Baker's-row, Walworth. On Tuesday, the 31st of Aug., I saw the prisoner take a coat down from the front of the prosecutor's shop—he folded it up, and ran away with it—there was another man with him—I am quite sure the prisoner took it.
JAMES CASTLETON (policeman, P 33.) I found the prisoner running, and took him into custody.
