WILLIAM COCKERELL (policeman, L 108.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction at this court—(read—Convicted the 21st of Sept., 1846, having been before convicted of felony, and confined nine months)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY. Aged 47.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2258.
MARGARET WARD was indicted
for stealing 18 yards of ribbon value 4s.; 5 yards of blonde, 5d.; 9 yards of lace, 5s.; 1 frill, 1s. 6d.; 9 yards of calico, 2s.; 1 apron, 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, 8d.; 9 yards of cotton, 6d.; and 1 handkerchief, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Richard Ensoll, her master.

RICHARD ENSOLL. I am a draper and haberdasher, in Lambeth-walk—the prisoner was my servant—I missed several things, and asked to search her box—I did so, with an officer, and found all the articles named in the in
dictment, which are here produced; they are mine, and have my marks on them—they have not been sold by me—the prisoner had been with me seven months—she has borne a good character up to this time.
THOMAS RICHARD CARTER (police-inspector.) I was present when the prisoner's box was searched, and these things found in it.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

2259.
FANNY WARREN was indicted
for stealing 5lbs. weight of leather, value 7s.; the goods of
Henry Walker Williams; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined Three Months.

2260.
THOMAS NURSE was indicted
for stealing 1 half-crown, the moneys of
William Rowe, from his person.

WILLIAM ROWE. I live in King-street, East-lane, Walworth. On the afternoon of the 19th of Sept. I was in Battersea-fields, in company with George Double and Thomas Ball—I found the prisoner there with a donkey—I bargained with him for a ride for a penny—I had a halfpenny and a half-crown—I gave him the halfpenny into his hand for the half-crown—I took it out of his hand, and gave him the half-crown—he said, "Go on, you shall have your change when you come back, "and he struck the donkey before I got my legs across—he did not follow the donkey—I went a little way down—when I came back, the prisoner was not there, but another man took the donkey—I afterwards saw the prisoner amongst some men and some donkeys—I asked him for my change—he said, "Go on, you d—d liar, you are to have no change; you gave me two halfpence."

GEORGE DOUBLE. I live in Eagle-street—I was with Rowe in Batterses fields—I saw him give the prisoner a halfpenny first, and he said, "The won't do, "and he gave him a half-crown, and the halfpenny fell out of his hand again—the prisoner struck the donkey before he got his leg across, and he said, "Go on, you shall have your change when you come back"—we found the prisoner a few minutes afterwards, and he said that Rowe had only given him two halfpence, and one was a large halfpenny, the other a small one.

THOMAS BELL. I live in Bedford-row—I was with Rowe and Double—Rowe gave the prisoner a halfpenny—he then gave him the half-crown, and the halfpenny fell into his hand again—he said, "Give me my change?"—he said, "Go on, you shall have it when you come back"—he strack the donkey, and it ran away with the boy half-way down the field.

WILLIAM WALKER (policeman, L 98.) I was on duty last Sunday evening in Battersea-fields—I apprehended the prisoner—I found on him two six-pences, which he gave to another man to get food for his donkey.
Prisoner. I had two sixpences in my pocket; I told the policeman that was all I had got; this boy had given me two halfpence, and I gave them for change for a sixpence.

COURT to WILLIAM ROWE. Q. Since this occurred, has your master made a charge against you? A. Yes, about receiving 1l. 14s.—I was examined before the Magistrate about it—this half-crown has nothing to do with that—I meant to let the prisoner have the half-crown, and to give me 2s. 5d. change, but the halfpenny fell into his hand—I expected he would give me 2s. 5 1/2d.

2261.
HARRIET MOORE was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 1l. 5s.; 4 jackets, 1l. 12s.; 5 waistcoats, 15s.; 11 shirts, 1l. 2s.; 4 books, 1l.; 5 handkerchiefs, 12s. 6d; 7 blankets, 1l. 8s.; 3 counterpanes,10s.; 4 pairs of trowsers, 1l. 2s.; 2 table-cloths, 5s.; 1 pair of drawers, 2s.; 1 sheet, 3s.; 2 pairs of stockings, 2s.; and 6 yards of flannel, 5s.; the goods of
Peter Tagg, her master.

PETER TAGG. I am a slop-seller, and live in Tooley-street, Southwark—the prisoner was in my service, on and off, for three of four years. On Sunday, the 22nd of Aug., she was there, and I gave her into custody—I then went to her lodging, I knew where she lived, as she has been with me so long—the policeman went with me—we found thirty-eight duplicates—I have seen some property of mine at the pawnbroker's—they are here—most of them are mine—five or six of the pawnbrokers gave up the goods—my daughter discovered it, and I told the prisoner to put on her bonnet and shawl, and go with me—she said, "For God's sake, Mr. Tagg, "or "master, forgive me"—my daughter told her she heard her walk in the shop, and my second daughter charged her with stealing a pair of drawers—she professed innocence—she then said she was sorry, and begged I would forgive her.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. It was about the drawers that she said she was very sorry? A. And also about a pair of boots and a waist-coat—I went to her house the same day—I knew it was her house—I was in the habit of sending my boy to her—I think I was once at her house, eigh
teen months ago, and left some message for her.

JOHN HIGHWOOD (policeman, M 102.) On the 22nd of Aug. I was on duty in Tooley-street—I went to Mr. Tagg's, and took the prisoner into custody—Mr. Tagg charged her with stealing a pair of drawers, and a pair of boots—she said, "Mr. Tagg, do forgive me this time; I will never do the like again"—I took her to the station—I went on the Monday to several pawnbrokers, and I got a great many articles, which have been shown to Mr. Tagg—the prisoner gave her address No. 34, Brunswick-court, Bermondsey—I went there on the Sunday, and saw a man, who called himself Moore—I found there thirty-eight duplicates, and from them I got the articles at the pawnbrokers—the prisoner owned to the drawers and boots, on the Monday, before the Magistrate, but said she knew nothing about the waistcoat; but of the following Monday, the 30th, she acknowledged everything—she said she could not say but what she had pawned the articles—one dress she said was her own—I should think there were forty pledges.
ANN ASLETT. I searched the prisoner at the station—I found on her twenty-two duplicates, a penknife, and a seal—I marked the duplicates, and gave them up.

HENRY COTTAM. I am a pawnbroker. I produce twenty-five articles, twenty-two of which have been claimed by Mr. Tagg—the prisoner pawned them between Nov., 1846, and June, 1847—the policeman has the dupli
cates which I gave her from time to time.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen the prisoner often? A. Very often—I have known her for the last eleven years pawning at my house—here is a coat and a shirt pawned on the 31st of May—I recollect taking them in—I began then to have some doubt about the matter, and I asked her two or three questions—that was the first time I had suspicion—there were one or two pawnings in June, but I did not take them in—these are the things pawned on the 31st of May.

PETER TAGG
re-examined. These are mine—this coat was made only a few days before it was lost, for a person who never came for it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you make it? A. No, certainly not—here is a pair of shoes of mine—I did not make them—this flannel waistcoat I cut out—I cut out all the slops—if I have a bespoke order, I have a foreman to cut it—I bought some of these shoes only two days before—one pair was sold, and another pair was missed immediately after.

GUILTY. Aged 38.—
Confined One Year.

2262.
HARRIET MOORE was again indicted
for stealing 1 pair of drawers, value 3s.; 1 pair of shoes, 5s.; and 1 waistcoat, 2s.; the goods of
Peter Tagg, her master: to which she pleaded

2263.
MARGARET ANDREWS alias M'Carty
, was indicted
for steal
ing 48 yards of diaper, value 1l. 12s.; the goods of
George Bucknall Picken; having been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM MORTON (police-sergeant P 7.) On the 2nd of Sept., I was walk
ing down East-lane, Walworth—I saw the prisoner with this bundle under her shawl, in an apron—I heard a whistle—the prisoner looked round—when I got within a few yards of her, she threw down this bundle, and I saw this ticket fall from it—I took her—she tried her best to get away from me—I asked her how she got the bundle—she said she met a man going down Newington-causeway, and asked him to stand a drop of gin, and he said he would if she carried this bundle—I stopped her about 100 yards from Mr. Picken's shop, near Newington-causeway—it is a good half mile from there.

Prisoner. I dropped the bundle on account of its weight; I had no reason to run away; I did not know it was a policeman; I thought it was a gentle
man catching hold of me.

ELIZABETH BARRETT. I live in Ann's-place, East-lane. I was in East-lane on the 2nd of Sept., and saw the prisoner throw down this bundle—I took it up—I saw the officer go after her—he had a box with him—she tried to get away from him—I took it from him, or he would have had to throw it down—she tore her shawl in trying to get away.

GEORGE BUCKNALL PICKEN. I live in Crosby-row, Walworth. This diaper in this bundle is mine—it has my private mark on it—it is worth about 30s. or 2l.—this ticket is mine—where the prisoner was stopped is about 100 yards from my shop.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not aware it was stolen; a man asked me to carry it; I do not know his name.

ELIZABETH BARRETT
re-examined. The prisoner turned several times before she saw the officer—when she saw him she threw it down.
RICHARD DAVIS (policeman, P 55.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted Aug., 1846, and confined fourteen days)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY.* Aged 18.—
Confined One Year.

2264.
ELIZABETH TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of shoes, value 4s.; the goods of
James Dawson.

JOSEPH RAKESTRAW (policeman, L 120.) On the evening of the 15th of Sept., I found the prisoner in Cross-street, Walworth—she was intoxicated—I took her to the station, and found on her two pairs of shoes and a pair of boots—when she was sober I asked her for an account of them—she said the boots belonged to her, and one pair of the shoes—I asked her what she could
say about the third pair—she said she was not aware she had a third pair—she did not give me her true address—I have found it out since.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Did not she say No. 1, Salisburry-crescent, Kent-road? A. Yes, and I believe it is called Salisbury-cottages—one is opposite to the other—it is in Lock's-fields, close by the Kent-road—I saw the prisoner about seven o'clock in the evening—she did not tell me where she bought them.

FRANCES WIRE. I am shopwoman to Mr. James Dawson—he keeps a shoe-warehouse in Newington-causeway. The prisoner brought a pair of shoes to be repaired, and she came on the following Wednesday to fetch them—she bought a pair of boots, and paid for them—this pair of shoes, produced, came out of our shop—we have sold a great many pairs, but not of this make—the prisoner sat with her back to the place where these shoes were—she was sober—the boots were 3s. 6d. a pair, and the shoes 4s.—I am sure these shoes were there in the morning.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe she had dealt at your shop for some time? A. I believe so—I believe her face is known there, and her foot also—I can swear these shoes are my master's—they are a particular made shoe—there are the marks of the size on them—there was no other pair of this size, of this particular make—I cannot tell how many pairs of shoes were in the shop—there were others of this size but not of this material—it is patent seal—I dare say it was about three o'clock when she came—we were very busy; there were many persons in the shop—there was one shopman and one shopwoman besides me; they are not here, they sell shoes as I do—I did not miss these shoes till my attention was called to them by the policeman—I served the prisoner—she paid 3s. 6d. for the boots, and 6d. for the shoes being mended, and went away—I had seen her on the Saturday previous when she brought the shoes.
COURT. Q. As you were a good deal occupied, could you say positively she was not the worse for loquor? A. From her manner of speaking I should say she was not.

COURT to JOSEPH RAKESTRAW. Q. She was too much intoxicated to give any account to you? A. Yes; that was about seven o'clock or a little after—there was no one with her—she was in a pie-shop—the girl was taking some pains with her—when the master came home she flew at him and scratched his face, that brought me in contact with her—the master got her out and brought the shoes to me—the prisoner said they were hers, and she had some money—I took her because she had this property and money—the shoes that were mended, she has on now I believe—these new shoes and boots she had in her hand.

2265.
PETER TAYLOR.
THOMAS HEARN
, and
JOHN ALLEN , were indicted for
stealing 20 lbs. weight of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
Edward Herring.

EDWIN BAKER. I am manager to Mr. Edward Herring, of Trinity-street, St. Mary, Newington. He is a manufacturer of salphate of quinine—he has certain vessels in his manufactory lined with lead, which requires repairing from time to time—the prisoners were employed on the premises a few days ago—they were employed on Thursday the 9th, and of Friday the 10th of Sept.—I gave some directions to Smart and to Lomas—the prisoners left the premises about twenty minutes after five o'clock on Friday evening—I

followed them to the corner of Blackman-street—Trinity-street runs is to Blackman-street—Allen them remained behind with another plumber, and Taylor and Hearn crossed over to Suffolk-street—I should followed them—Hearn left Taylor and went along Suffolk-street, and Taylor commenced running up Blackman-street—I followed Taylor up a stable-yard, and in the yard I saw him take two pieces of lead out of his waistcoat-pocket, and throw them into a window, which was partly open; I laid hold of him—he had them one piece of lead in his hand—I took possession of that, and afterwards got the two pieces of lead from the window—there were about 20 bls. weight of it—it be
longed to Mr. Edward Herring—it had been on his premises.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How long had Hearn and Allen been employed there? A. Allen only the day previous, Hearn several times for about two months—there was nothing found on Hearn, or Allen, or at their lodging.

Cross-examined by MR. CAARTEEN. Q. Has Mr. Herring any partner? A. No—I have been there about eight months—it is called the "British and Foreign Alkali Company"—Mr. Herring centres in himself the whole of that body—he has told me so—I reside on the premises—Mr. Herring re
sides at Wandsworth—he attends to the business himself, as I do—I have never seen any partner but him.

JAMES MOORE SMART. I took at Mr. Herring's manufactory. On Friday evening, the 10th of Sept., I watched the three prisoners—I went down stairs about ten minutes before five, and about five minutes before five o'clock Hearn came down—he took something off the right side of the bench in the plumbers' workshop, which appeared to be solder—he doubled it up, and put it into his left waistcoat pocket—he went away, and returned a second time—he bent up some piping, or some sheet lead, I cannot swear which, and secreted that about his person—he went away, and come back the third time—he than beat up some sheet lead, and placed it under his waistcoat—while he was so doing Taylor came down—he beat up three pieces of sheet lead, and placed them under his waistcoat—then Allen came down—he beat up two pieces of sheet lead, and placed them under his waistcoat—they then went up stairs—I went up as quick as I could, and ordered the people in the warehouse to shut the gates, but the prisoners were gone out—I and Bake followed Taylor—I saw him taken in the yard by Baker—I saw Baker pick up one piece of lead—I saw Taylor give Baker one piece, and one piece to Lomas—of course it was lead taken from my master's premises—he went to no other place, because Mr. Baker was after him—I took Allen; he said he knew nothing of it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you? A. In the wine-cellar, about twenty yards from the workshop—it is under the warehouse, but in a line with the plumbers' shop—I looked through the open—work of the door—it is a kind of grating—there is about two inches space between each bar—I saw Hearn take something that seemed to he solder, but I cannot say what—Taylor come down while Hearn was down the third time—he beat up three pieces of lead, and placed them under his waistcoat—the prisoners were all together before they went away, but they came in one at a time—Allen was taken the same evening at his own door—no property was found on him, or at his house.

COURT. Q. Did you see Allen do anything? A. Yes, beat up two pieces of lead, and place them under his waistcoat—Hearn was in there three separate times, and the last time he was in, Taylor came, and directly after
wards Allen came in—they could see one another take it.

Cross-examined by MR. CAARTEEN. Q. Who came first into the shop? A. Hearn—I do not knew where the other two prisoners were at the time Hearn took what I considered to be solder—Hearn then left, and came again, and beat up something—I cannot say whether it was piping or sheet lead—neither of the other prisoners were there then—Hearn went away, and came again the third time, and beat up some sheet lead—while he was there Taylor and Allen came—the place is about ten feet long, and eight feet, wide—the man had done work at that time—the prisoners were as near together as they could be—the sheet lead is on the side of the workshop, they were all three at that lead.

JAMES LOMAS. I am in Mr. Herring's service. On Friday afternoon, the 10th of Sept., Mr. Baker told me to watch—I watched, and saw Hearn take two pieces of leaden pipe, about nine inches long—he placed them about his body, and went away—he came back again, and took a piece of sheet lead, he beat it together, and put that about his body, under his waistcoat—he went out, and came in the third time, took some more lead, beat it together, and placed that about his body—Taylor then came in, beat up three pieces of lead, and placed it about his body—I did not see Allen come in, for I left Hearn and Taylor in the room when I went up into the warehouse to give Information to a man to go for a policemen—I then went and watched again—I saw the three prisoners together in the room—they were standing together, and feeling one another down, to see whether they would be noticed in going out—they than came up stairs, and went out—I followed them to the bottom of Trinity-street—they crossed, and Taylor turned towards St. George's Church—I saw Baker run after him—I followed him—he turned down a stable-yard, and there threw away some lead.

CHARLES WALKER (police-sergeant, M 18.) On Friday, the 10th of Sept, Taylor was given into my charge, and this lead was brought to the station by Mr. Baker—Taylor said the foremen give him the lead to take to the shop.

JOSHUA GOLDIN (policeman M 87.) I took Hearn that evening in Bedford
bury—I told him what it was for; he said he knew nothing at all of it—I told him I took on a charge of stealing lead from Mr. Herring's premises, where he had been working that day—he said he knew nothing about stealing lead, but he knew there was something up when he saw them following them.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

TAYLOR—
GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

HEARN—
GUILTY. Aged 27.

ALLEN—
GUILTY. Aged 29.

2266.
EDWARD WALKER was indicted
for stealing 1 clock, value, 1s.; 6 ounces weight of silver, 1l. 4s.; the property of
William walker; to which he pleaded

GUILTY.—
Confined Three Months.

2267.
ROBERT SALMON was indicted for
stealing 112lbs. weight of lead, value 2l. 10s.; the goods of
Richard Sterry, his master; and
AARON PAYNE
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

RICHARD STERRY. I am an oilman, and live in High-street, Borough; my son and two others are partners with me. I had some lead on the roof of my own private house at Croydon—I had a new roof put on that house—the old lead had been removed—I sold it to Warner and Sons—Salmon was a carman in our service—he was sent to Croydon for the purpose of removing the lead, and he was ordered to call at our place in the Borough—he would have no business in Bermondsey-street with the cart on the 31st of Aug.—it is not in the direction from Croydon to my house in the Borough, or to Mr. Warner's—this lead worth 17s. a cwt.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. I suppose you do not know where Salmon lives? A. No.; I never knew where he lived—I understood he was in the service of Chaplin and Horne, before he came to us—I do not think we had a character with him—he was employed as a temporary carman while our man was ill—he drove the wagon about a month.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Who cut the lead at your country house? A. It was cut by a labourer—I sent a person to the police-office to identify some lead—I was there at the time—he was examined before the Magistrate—he is not a witness in this case—he answered the questions put by the Magistrate, but his testimony amounted to nothing.

GEORGE ADAMS (policeman 156 M.) On the 31st of Aug., between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, I was in Bermondsey-street, and met Salmon driving a wagon—he was coming in a direction from Payne's house—he asked me to drink, and I drank with him—he asked me to mind his wagon—I did so, and he went away for nearly ten minutes—he then came and turned his horses round, and went back, past Payne's shop—in Salmon's absence I had looked into his wagon, and found it contained lead—I received some information, and went to Payne's shop—I asked him whether he had bought any lead—he said no, he had not—Salmon was passing the door at the time, and I said to Payne, "Your bought some lead of that man"—he said yes, he had, but he had not paid him for it—it then left Payne, and went and overtook Salmon at the corner of Tooley-street—I told him he had been selling some lead to Mr. Payne—he said he had not—I said he had, for Mr. Payne had told me so—he said he hoped I would say nothing about it—he produced 5s., and begged of me to say nothing about it—I threw the five shillings on the ground, and Salmon got into his eat and drove away—I knew him very well, and where he worked—I then returned to Payne's shop, and told him I should go and inform Mr. Sterry of the circumstance—he followed me out of the shop, and begged me not to do it, and offered me half a sovereign—he followed me to Snows'-fields, urging me to receive the money and say noting about it—I did not take the money.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How long have you known Salmon! A. I think nearly three years—he lives in Cherry-garden-street, Dockhead, or somewhere near there—that is below where I saw him—I did not see his wife or children in the cart that day—the cart was coming back towards High-street when I first saw it, as if he had been further down—we had a pot of beer together before he left me—I should say it would take him half an hour to go from where I met him, to his own house—I do not know is whose service he was—I have seen him repeatedly driving a van—the cart appeared to have a full load.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. What time did you go to Payne's!

A. About six o'clock—I did not search Payne's house; Wilde searched it—it was rather an oversight of mine that I did not search the house at six o'clock—I have been about three years in the police—when he offered me 10s. to compromise a felony, I neither searched his house nor took him into custody—there is a marine-store dealer's next to Payne's; I went in there first—I did not address myself to that store-dealer, I came out again—there is a gateway next to Payne's, it dose not project at all; the front of it is in the same line with the front of his house—I received information, and went to Payne's—the person who gave me the information is not here—he was sum
moned before the Magistrate, but was not called.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. From the time Salmon left the cart till he came back, could he have gone to his own house? A. No, it was impossible—he could have gone to Payne's after he had left me—he was moving the lead from the front of the cart to the back—I did not search Payne's house, but he admitted the lead was there—he said Salmon had left lead there, but he had not paid him for it—that was said before the half-sovereign was offered.

THOMAS ROGERS. I keep a shop in the archway across Bermondsey-street, On the 31st of Aug. I saw a cart in Bermondsey-street, opposite Payne's door—I saw Salmon take something out of the cart into Payne's marine store-shop—I could not tell what it was, it was rather heavy—he carried it in his arms, open—I was about thirty yards from it—he took it from the hind part of the cart.

COURT. Q. Was it open? A. Yes—I could not tell what it was—it was a light colour—it appeared to be heavy—this is my writing to this deposition—I sthink it might be wrapped up in something—I think it was wrapped up with something, because it was of a light appearance.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Was the railway between you and the cart? A. I was right under the railway—from the way in which he carried it, I should say it was heavy—he carried it openly in his arms—I was examined three or four days afterwards—I can recollect every circumstance for a month as well as for a week—it was between five and six o'clock—it was not raining—I live under the arch—I was in front of my own house—Payne lives on the opposite side to me—the cart was between us—I could see him leave the cart and go into the house—I had never seen the cart before that day—I did not see it pass down with some children in it—I keep a general shop.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. How long elapsed between the time you saw this and the first examination before the Magistrate? A. It hap
pened on Tuesday, and I think on the Monday following I went to the office—I was up twice—I was not examined till the 14th of Sept.—a fortnight elapsed before I was examined, but I was at the office four days before the police
man Adams came to me.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. When did you first mention this circumstance? A The next day—when I heard what had happened, I told the policeman—I saw the there—I saw Salmon sideways as he went in.

GEORGE NICHOL (policeman M 128.) I was on duty in Snows'-fields on the 31st of Aug.—I saw Adams talking to Payne—I might be two or three yards from them—I saw Payne put his hand into his pocket, take it out, and hold it towards Adams—I heard Adams say, "No, I will not take it"—I heard Payne say, "I hope you will not say anything about it then."

GEORGE WYLD (policeman M 94.) On the night of the 31st of Aug. I searched Payne's shop—I found this small piece of lead in small tub, like a butter-tub. under the counter—here is about 7lbs. of it—it is what they call cast lead.

WILLIAM SAMPSON. I am a labourer, and live at Croydon. I removed a quantity of old lead from Mr. Sterry's house there, about the 30th or 31st of Aug.—this piece looks like the same sort of lead—it was taken away in three loads—Salmon took one load on the 31st of Aug.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. The lead was generally in large pieces, was it not? A. Some of it was—there were pieces from 1lb. to 1cwt.—it is cast lead, not generally used, not in one house in thirty.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Can you tell which was the heaviest load? A. I suppose the last load—it was the largest in bulk—the first was lighter, the second heavier, and the third the heaviest.

THOMAS HURST. I am in the service of Mr. Warner, of Cripplegate. I received three loads of cast lead from Salmon in Aug.—the last load was on the 31st of Aug., at past seven o'clock in the evening—I told him I thought he was very late—he said he had made all the haste he could—I said, "Do you request to have it weighed to-night?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Well, we will weigh it"—the weight of the first load was 39cwt. 3qrs., the second 31cwt. 3qrs. 26lbs., and the third 27cwt. 2qrs. 21lbs.—the second lcad was 8cwt. lighter than the first, and was 4cwt. heavier than the third.

MR. PARRY to GEORGE WYLD. Q. Do not you know that Payne has as one or two occasions given information of parties who wanted to sell his stolen goods? A. I believe that is the case—I have been to his shop several times when anything has been missing, and he has always told me that if anything happened he would let me know momentarily.

2268.
CHARLES DOUGLASS was indicted
for stealing 1 breast-pin, value 10s.; 2 brooches, 2d.; I sovereign; and 1 half-sovereign; the property of
Joseph Brown; having been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH BROWN. I am pot-boy at the Prince's Head public-house, a Richmond. I had a sovereign, a half-sovereign, and a gold pin, on the 20th of Aug.—on Saturday night, at six o'clock, the window of my room was safe, and everything all close—on Sunday, between twelve and one o'clock, I went to get my clean things in my room up stairs, and saw the window was open, and one pane of glass was broken—I went into the room, and found my box was broken open—I looked into it, and found a sovereign and a half had been taken out, and a gold pin and two brooches—when I had done my business I went to look for a policeman, and told him what I had lost—I told him had suspicion of the prisoner—when I came back the prisoner was in the tap
room—the officer questioned him where he was the night before—he said he was at the Waterman's Arms till a quarter to eleven o'clock, and then he went to the Queen's Head, and was there from a quarter to eleven till a quarter is twelve on Saturday night, and while he was there he saw the pin offered for sale.
Prisoner. Q. Did you say you saw me there? A. No, I went to inquire, and they said you were not there.
HENRY MAGNUS. I keep a clothes-shop at Richmond. On Sunday morning, the 22nd of Aug., about twelve o'clock, the prisoner came to me to buy a coat—I sold him one for 5s.

GEORGE GOODWIN. I keep a beer-shop. The prisoner was there on this Saturday night from seven o'clock till a quarter before ten—he asked me for credit for a pint of beer, and told me he had no money—he came the next morning and had some tea and bread and butter, which came to 6d.—he went
out again, and came to dinner—he had as much as came to 9d.—he paid me about half-a-crown in all—it was between one and two o'clock.
Prisoner. My dinner came to 7d.; I had no beer. Witness. You had a pint of beer, which made it 9d.
STEPHEM HAYNES. I keep a public-house. The prisoner was not at my house from eleven to twelve o'clock on that Saturday night, to my knowledge.
Prisoner. I came into your tap-room at ten minutes before eleven o'clock, and staid till half-past eleven.
PHILIP PAGE. I saw the prisoner in front of the Prince's Head at ten minutes before eleven o'clock on that Saturday night.

WILLIAM SELBY EDMID (policeman V 32.) I went to the Prince's Head on the Sunday, and examined the premises—the prisoner came in while I was there—I asked him where he was the night before—he said he was at the Waterman's Arms till a quarter before eleven o'clock, and then he went to the Queen's Head, and stopped till a quarter to twelve—I asked if he had seen any
body that afternoon offering jewellery for sale—he said, "No"—he then said he had heard of it, while he was at the Queen's Head, that two persons came in and pulled something out of their pockets, and said they should be able to get something for it—he described it as a shirt-pin—he said, after he was at the Queen's Head he went home, and slept in his father's cellar—I searched there, and found this iron tool, which exactly corresponds with the marks on the window—here is the window-frame(produced)—this tool exactly fits the marks on it—I believe this tool opened the window.

Prisoner. He picked up this tool out of a dozen more; it is what we use for fixing timbers on the saw-pit. Witness. There was not another like it—this was lying on the top of a tub in the cellar—the others were all pointed, this is not.

JOSEPH BROWN
re-examined. Q. How far is the Queen's Head from you? A. About a minute's walk, hardly that—my room is over the stable.
Prisoner's Defence. The gates are left open for anybody; I was never near the house; I had the money saved up to buy me a jacket; I was going to play a cricket-match with Mr. Goodwin.
GEORGE GOODWIN. Yes—you paid me half-a-crown a week before that, to play.
JURY to W. S. EDMID. Q. Did you find any money on the prisoner? A. No—he told me he had no more money, or he should have bought the pin.

STEPHEN CREED (policeman V 200.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 30th Jan. 1843, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2269.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was indicted
for embezzling 1l. 2s. 10d., the moneys of
Thomas Twiddy and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY.—
Confined Nine Months.

2270.
MARY BROWN and
MARY ANN JOHNSON were indicted for
unlawfully attempting to obtain money by false pretences.

div0.p: MARY ANN HUNT , convicted at the last session of WILFUL MURDER,

p.hi: The prisoner was placed at the bar on Saturday, Sept. 25th, before Mr. Baron Platt; and being asked whether she had anything to say in stay of execution, pleaded that she was pregnant. A

was accord
ingly summoned, who, after having retired and examined the prisoner, found that she was not quick with child. The learned
stated that the law must take its course.
